stem: A 68-year-old right-handed man is brought by ambulance to the emergency department after his wife found him unresponsive. The wife states that her husband had not been feeling well for the last 12 hours. He woke up this morning complaining of dizziness, neck pain, unsteadiness, and headache. As the day progressed, his symptoms worsened and he started vomiting. Towards the evening, the patient was lethargic and more confused than at his baseline. He has not had any fevers or chills. His medical problems include mild dementia, poorly controlled hypertension, hyperlipidemia, ischemic stroke due to untreated high-grade left carotid artery stenosis, COPD on home oxygen, and chronic low back pain treated with oxycontin and hydrocodone. He lives with his wife and depends on her for most of his activities of daily living. For the past several months, his wife has had more difficulty taking care of him and administering his medications properly. She states that the patient has been abusing his narcotic medications. His temperature is 37.1 C (98.8 F), blood pressure is 170/110 mm Hg, pulse is 40/min, and oxygen saturation is 85% on room air. His general physical examination reveals a left carotid bruit, S4 gallop, and prominent expiratory wheezes with reduced air flow. On neurological examination, he appears comatose. Cranial nerve testing reveals absence of blink-to-threat, mid-position fixed and dilated pupils, absence of oculocephalic reflex, and presence of corneal, gag, and cough reflexes. Motor examination reveals extensor posturing in the upper and lower extremities. Reflexes are absent and plantar responses are mute. He does not grimace to pain. Which of the following is the most likely etiology for this patient's presentation?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with likely acute hypertensive cerebellar hemorrhage causing increased intracranial pressure and secondary upward transtentorial herniation. Hypertensive hemorrhages most commonly occur in the basal ganglia and thalamus. However, they can also occur in the cerebellum, pons, and even the lobar regions (~10%). Patients typically present acutely with severe headache, nausea/vomiting, vertigo, unsteadiness, and mental status changes. Space occupying lesions (e.g., hemorrhage) in the small posterior fossa can quickly obliterate the fourth ventricle to cause obstructive hydrocephalus, increased intracranial pressure (ICP), and Cushing's reflex (hypertension, bradycardia, and Cheyne-Stokes breathing). The increased ICP can cause the cerebellum to herniate upwards to compress the mid-brain (areflexic pupils, impaired oculocephalics, and extensor posturing as seen in this patient), or downwards to compress the medulla oblongata (ataxic breathing, loss of gag and cough reflexes). This patient needs urgent imaging to confirm the diagnosis as well as likely surgical decompression. (Choice B) Enteroviral meningitis usually occurs in the summer/early fall and presents with severe headache, fever, malaise, and neck rigidity. However, these patients usually maintain normal mental status. (Choice C) Hypercapnia due to severe COPD exacerbation can cause headache and depressed mental status. However, it does not usually trigger a Cushing's reflex or profuse vomiting. (Choice D) Middle cerebral artery occlusion usually presents with hemiparesis, but typically does not cause extensor posturing as seen in this patient. (Choice E) Opiate intoxication will typically cause pinpoint pupils, but will not trigger a Cushing's reflex.

stem: A 54-year-old man with a history of seizure disorder is brought to the emergency department with progressive lethargy over the last 2 days. He has not had any headache, fever, or flu-like symptoms. He had a severe allergic reaction to levetiracetam in the past and failed phenytoin therapy. He is currently maintained on valproic acid. His last generalized tonic-clonic seizure was 1 week ago and his neurologist doubled the dose of his valproic acid at that time. The patient's past medical history is also significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Additional medications include metformin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. The patient's temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. pulse is, 70/min, and respirations are 12/min. Pulse oximetry shows 96% on room air. His BMI is 29 kg/m2. On examination he appears lethargic, but is arousable, oriented to person and place, and follows simple commands. Laboratory values are as follows: Complete blood count Hemoglobin 11.8 g/dL Leukocytes 9,000/uL Serum chemistry Sodium 136 mEq/L Potassium 3.8 mEq/L Chloride 102 mEq/L Bicarbonate 24 mEq/L Blood urea nitrogen 18 mg/dL Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL Calcium 8.8 mg/dL Glucose 110 mg/dL Liver function studies Aspartate aminotransferase 37 U/L Alanine aminotransferase 24 U/L Urinalysis and urine drug screen are normal. Chest x-ray and non-contrast head CT are normal. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This patient is likely presenting with valproic acid induced hyperammonemic encephalopathy related to the recent doubling of his valproic acid dose. Valproic acid can inhibit enzymes within the urea cycle and lead to elevated serum ammonia levels resulting in confusion, lethargy, coma, and rarely death. All patients on valproic acid who present with encephalopathy should have their serum ammonia and valproic acid levels checked as part of the workup. Valproic acid levels do not always correlate with the degree of encephalopathy and can be normal at times. Liver enzymes can also be normal despite elevations in ammonia levels. The mainstay of treatment is discontinuation of valproic acid. Synthetic disaccharides such as lactulose can be used to lower the serum ammonia levels, and L-carnitine has been shown to improve valproic acid metabolism and reduce ammonia levels as well. (Choice B) Creatine kinase (CK) can be elevated in rhabdomyolysis (eg, from prolonged convulsive seizure activity and/or statin toxicity) but is unlikely to be useful in this patient as he does not have muscle pain or weakness, has a normal basic metabolic panel, and his urinalysis does not show blood. (Choice C) Metformin toxicity typically occurs in patients with concomitant renal or liver disease or as a result of acute overdose. A major complication is lactic acidosis. Patients classically present with gastrointestinal symptoms, followed by altered mental status, dyspnea, and hypotension. This patient's lack of gastrointestinal symptoms and normal calculated anion gap (10 mEq/L) make this diagnosis unlikely. (Choices D and E) Lumbar puncture and brain MRI can be considered in patients with an unclear cause of acute altered mental status and a negative head CT, but this patient should have his serum ammonia level checked first.

stem: A 71-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to not feeling well and worsening right leg weakness. The patient had a stroke 2 years ago and has mild residual right leg weakness. Over the last 2 days, her weakness has gotten worse compared to her baseline, and she can hardly ambulate with a cane. The patient has a history of persistent atrial fibrillation and takes daily warfarin. Her temperature is 38.3 C (101 F), blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg, pulse is 94/min, and respirations are 14/min. Pulse oximetry shows 97% on room air. Neurologic examination shows spastic right lower extremity weakness and hyperreflexia. A noncontrast head CT reveals an old infarct in the left anterior cerebral artery territory. Laboratory results are as follows: Hematocrit 48% Platelets 180,000/uL Leukocytes 14,000/uL International Normalized Ratio 2.8 Urinalysis Leukocyte esterase Positive Nitrites Positive White blood cells 100+/hpf Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
choice_b: Exacerbation of prior stroke symptoms by infection
explanation: This patient presents with worsening of her previous stroke symptoms due to a urinary tract infection. Acute exacerbations of prior neurologic deficits may happen in conjunction with acute infection or metabolic derangement and can sometimes be difficult to distinguish from a new ischemic event. This patient's current neurologic exacerbation is referable to the same vascular territory that was previously affected (eg, left anterior cerebral artery infarction with contralateral lower extremity hemiparesis) and occurred in the setting of an acute infection; therefore, a new cardioembolic event is less likely, especially with a therapeutic International Normalized Ratio on warfarin (Choice E). Diffusion-weighted brain MRI can always be considered if any uncertainty exists or if diagnostic confirmation is required. (Choice A) Acute spinal cord compression (eg, from spontaneous epidural hematoma or epidural abscess) is unlikely in the absence of back pain. (Choice C) L5 radiculopathy is a result of nerve root irritation, and symptoms follow a dermatomal pattern. It usually presents with lower back pain radiating down the ipsilateral leg and can be associated with foot drop and numbness along the anterolateral leg. This patient's focal upper motor neuron signs (eg, spasticity, hemiparesis, hyperreflexia) are consistent with an old cerebral infarction, not radiculopathy. (Choice D) Normal pressure hydrocephalus initially presents with ataxia, followed by dementia and urinary incontinence. Neuroimaging should demonstrate dilated ventricles, not an old infarction.

stem: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a sudden cardiac arrest. He collapsed at home while watching television. His son started CPR as instructed by the 911 operator. Emergency medical services arrived in 7 minutes. The initial rhythm was noted to be ventricular fibrillation, and the patient was successfully defibrillated to normal sinus rhythm with return of spontaneous circulation. The patient was intubated in the field, and intravenous amiodarone was administered. His medical problems include stable angina, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. Home medications include aspirin, metoprolol, enalapril, and atorvastatin. Blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg and pulse is 85/min. Examination shows scattered bilateral crackles. Heart sounds are normal. There is no response to painful stimulation. Oculocephalic and corneal reflexes are intact. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with ST segment depression in leads I, aVL, and V4-V6. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows no acute intracranial abnormality. Which of the following is most likely to increase the chance of complete neurologic recovery in this patient?
choice_a: Elevating blood pressure with fluid resuscitation
explanation: This patient has experienced a sudden cardiac arrest (SCA). Neurologic impairment is the most common cause of death following out-of-hospital SCA and is responsible for significant morbidity following in-hospital SCA. Temperature management (TM), consisting of avoidance of fever and maintenance of body temperature <=36 C (96.8 F) for 24-48 hours following SCA, has been shown to decrease mortality and improve neurologic recovery. TM is indicated in patients who are unresponsive or lack purposeful movements following SCA and should be initiated as soon as possible unless there is a contraindication. Because low temperature inhibits the coagulation cascade, active noncompressible bleeding is a relative contraindication. Absolute contraindications to TM include patient wishes against aggressive care or a medical scenario in which such care would be futile. Methods of TM include infusion of cold saline and application of topical cooling blankets. Body temperature is typically maintained between 32 C (89.6 F) and 36 C (96.8 F); however, the benefit of lowering body temperature to <36 C (96.8 F) is not clear. (Choice A) Elevating blood pressure with fluid repletion is beneficial in hypotensive patients to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) >80 mm Hg and optimize cerebral perfusion pressure. However, it is not indicated in this patient with adequate MAP who already appears slightly hypervolemic. (Choice B) Avoidance of hypoglycemia is important in post-SCA patients, and target serum glucose should be 140-180 mg/dL. However, TM is more important for improving neurologic recovery. (Choice C) Permissive hypercapnia is contraindicated in patients with known or suspected neurologic injury as it can raise intracranial pressure and further decrease cerebral perfusion pressure. (Choice E) Given the initial cardiac rhythm of ventricular fibrillation, this patient's SCA was most likely due to an acute coronary event. He needs coronary angiography with percutaneous coronary intervention as soon as possible to improve overall mortality. However, as he now has a perfusing heart rhythm with adequate MAP, such intervention is less likely to improve his level of neurologic recovery.

stem: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe right thigh pain for the last 4 weeks. Over the past two weeks, he has also noticed leg weakness that interferes with his walking. He has never had similar symptoms before. He had an unintentional weight loss of 15 lbs (6.8 kg) over the past 3 months. His other medical problems include type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He has no evidence of diabetic retinopathy or nephropathy. He had a right lung lobectomy for early stage, non-small cell lung cancer 7 years ago. He was evaluated in the emergency department on two occasions over the last 2 months for severe lightheadedness that occurred in the morning while getting out of bed. His medications include glyburide, metformin, simvastatin, lisinopril, and low-dose aspirin. His temperature is 37.0 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg (sitting) and 120/80 mm Hg (standing), and pulse is 90/min (sitting) and 105/min (standing). His BMI is 29 kg/m2. Neurological examination reveals normal mental status and cranial nerves. Manual motor testing reveals 3/5 strength in the right iliopsoas, hip adductors, and quadriceps with associated atrophy. Touch, pain, and temperature sensations are mildly decreased in this area. However, the hamstrings and distal muscles have 5/5 strength. There are no fasciculations or contractures noted. His anal sphincter tone is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ in the arms and 0 in the lower extremities. Testing for Babinski sign shows down-going toes bilaterally. The remainder of the neurological examination is within normal limits. Laboratory results are as follows: Serum creatinine 1.3 mg/dL, Creatine kinase, serum 290 U/L, HemoglobinA1c 8%, Thyroid stimulating hormone 2.3 uU/mL, Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 28 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this patient's current complaints?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with diabetic amyotrophy (also known as proximal diabetic neuropathy or diabetic polyradiculopathy), which is a lumbosacral plexopathy that also affects the lumbosacral nerve roots and peripheral nerves. The pathophysiology is unclear but may be attributed to a nonsystemic microvasculitis leading to ischemic injury. Diabetic amyotrophy usually occurs in individuals over age 50 and in recently diagnosed or reasonably well-controlled diabetics (e.g., HbA1C ~7.5%). Patients classically present with acute and asymmetric focal proximal lower extremity pain associated with weakness, autonomic dysfunction (e.g., orthostatic hypotension), and unintentional weight loss (usually > 10 lbs). Diagnosis is made clinically and is usually a diagnosis of exclusion after other possible etiologies (e.g., cauda equina syndrome, Guillain-Barre syndrome, myositis/myopathy, structural plexus lesion, infections, and autoimmune or inflammatory conditions) are ruled out. An EMG/NCS can confirm the diagnosis. Over 60% of patients will notice improvement of their strength and pain symptoms within 12-24 months, but many may have residual weakness and pain. Since there is no definitive therapy, treatment usually involves symptomatic management including physical and occupational therapy, medication for pain control, and strict glycemic control. (Choice A) Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) usually presents with a combination of upper motor neuron (e.g., hyperreflexia, spasticity) and lower motor neuron (e.g., atrophy, fasciculations) symptoms. Although asymmetric limb weakness is the main presentation, patients usually complain of distal muscle weakness (e.g., foot drop, dropping things) first. In addition, severe pain is not seen with ALS. (Choice C) Extramedullary tumor with compressive myelopathy usually presents with progressive weakness below the level of lesion with sensory loss, hyperreflexia, spasticity, and incontinence. This patient's focal involvement in the proximal right leg with normal anal sphincter tone and absent lower extremity reflexes makes this diagnosis unlikely. (Choice D) Polymyositis typically presents with symmetrical proximal muscle weakness with or without pain. ESR, CRP, CPK, and aldolase levels are usually elevated. This patient's asymmetrical weakness without marked CPK elevation makes this condition less likely. (Choice E) The anterior and lateral femoral cutaneous nerves are pure sensory nerves and their compression does not cause muscle weakness or absent reflexes.

stem: A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with acute onset of severe headache followed by generalized tonic-clonic seizures. The patient was feeling well until 6 hours ago, when she developed a 10/10 throbbing bilateral headache associated with blurry vision. Her headache is not exacerbated by change in head position, and nothing seems to improve the pain. She denies any nausea, vomiting, photophobia, vertigo, fever, or neck pain. She also denies any recent head or neck trauma. She has had upper respiratory tract symptoms for the last couple of days. Her other medical problems include chronic migraines and non-essential hypertension related to renal artery stenosis from fibromuscular dysplasia. Her medications include topiramate and multiple anti-hypertensive agents including amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, and metoprolol. She also takes birth control pills and vitamins. She has never had a seizure before and has no family history of epilepsy. She works as a secretary and has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 10 years. Her temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 210/140 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min and regular, and respirations are 18/min with normal oxygen saturation. The general physical examination is unremarkable, except for an abdominal bruit. Neurological examination reveals that she is awake and alert, but is only oriented to person and place. Funduscopic examination reveals copper and silver wiring in the retina without papilledema. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Visual acuity is 20/200 bilaterally with intact visual fields to confrontation. There is no nystagmus and extra-ocular movements are full. The remainder of the neurological examination is unremarkable. A non-contrast head CT showed hypodense regions with loss of grey-white matter differentiation in the posterior occipital-parietal lobes. An MRI of the brain without gadolinium showed a symmetrical, increased T2/FLAIR signal abnormality in the subcortical white matter of the posterior occipital-parietal lobes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient's presentation is suggestive of posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES), which is a clinical radiologic syndrome due to a variety of conditions. It is often seen in the setting of hypertensive crises (hypertensive encephalopathy), chemotherapeutic agents (e.g., cyclosporine), eclampsia/preeclampsia, allogenic bone marrow transplantation, medical renal disease, autoimmune disease, sepsis, and shock. PRES is due to brain edema, possibly as a result of diminished sympathetic innervation of the posterior circulation. The posterior regions of the brain are more susceptible to injury from high mean arterial pressures, which lead to increased fluid migration into the brain parenchyma and subsequent vasogenic edema. It may also occur from cerebrovascular endothelial injury (vasculopathy). The parietal and occipital lobes are most commonly affected, followed by the frontal lobes, inferior temporal-occipital junction, and cerebellum. There have been rare case reports of PRES affecting the brainstem and the cervical cord as well. Diffusion weighted MRI studies of the brain are usually normal in the setting of PRES, and therefore confirm that the abnormalities seen in the cortical and subcortical white matter represent reversible vasogenic edema. Treatment includes lowering blood pressure and antiepileptic therapy for seizures, with most patients experiencing reversal of their symptoms within 2 weeks. (Choice A) This patient has fibromuscular dysplasia, which is also associated with cerebral aneurysms. However, subarachnoid hemorrhage usually presents with acute blood products in the cisterns on neuroimaging. (Choice B) Herpes simplex virus encephalitis can present with fever, headache, change in mental status, and seizures. However, imaging usually shows a high signal FLAIR/T2 abnormality with enhancement in the bilateral or unilateral temporal lobes. Herpes simplex virus encephalitis also does not typically present with visual loss. (Choice C) Idiopathic intracranial hypertension usually presents in young obese women with recurrent positional headaches (made worse in supine position) associated with visual obscurations, papilledema, and rarely visual loss. These patients typically do not develop seizures, and their MRI brain is usually unrevealing. (Choice D) Migraines typically present as a unilateral and throbbing headache evolving over hours with photophobia, phonophobia, and nausea/vomiting. Migraine headaches do not usually cause seizures or head MRI/CT imaging abnormalities.

stem: A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter for mild confusion, double vision, and frequent falls over the past 2-3 weeks. He has also been having headaches, decreased appetite, and nausea. His past medical history is significant for diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. The patient underwent resection of a malignant melanoma 2 months ago. His blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg and heart rate is 67/min. He appears comfortable and answers questions appropriately. There is no nuchal rigidity. Neurologic examination shows diplopia, mild weakness and spasticity of the right arm, and ataxic gait. Which of the following is the next best step in management of this patient?
choice_b: CT scan of the head with contrast
choice_d: MRI of the brain and spine
explanation: This patient is presenting with likely undiagnosed metastatic melanoma and leptomeningeal carcinomatosis (LC). Patients with LC typically present with the subacute onset (days to weeks) of headache and a variety of neurologic symptoms/signs including altered mental status, seizure, and/or multifocal neurologic deficits. LC is most frequently associated with metastatic solid tumors such as breast cancer, lung cancer, and malignant melanoma. The usual first step in evaluating a patient suspected of having LC is to obtain a gadolinium-enhanced MRI of the brain and spinal cord, which has a sensitivity of 76%-87%. Typical findings include linear or nodular leptomeningeal enhancement along the surface of the brain and spinal cord, enhancement of the cranial nerves or nerve roots, and/or hydrocephalus. Diagnosis can be made in patients with known metastatic cancer who have typical clinical presentations and MRI findings. A lumbar puncture is obtained in most patients after MRI as it increases diagnostic accuracy. However, it should be avoided in patients with large intracranial and/or spinal masses due to the risk of cerebral herniation. Furthermore, lumbar puncture performed before MRI can result in an artifact that can sometimes be confused with LC (Choice C). Typical findings include elevated opening pressure, low glucose, elevated protein, and mild lymphocytotic pleocytosis. Cytology should also be analyzed and is considered the gold standard for diagnosis (highly specific), but can be negative in up to 20% of cases. (Choice A) Empiric therapy with intravenous acyclovir is indicated for suspected herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis due to the high mortality rate if treatment is delayed. Patients with HSV encephalitis can present with the rapid onset of fever, headache, altered mental status, ataxia, and flaccid paralysis. However, this patient's subacute presentation, lack of fever, and spastic muscle weakness make this diagnosis less likely. (Choice B) This patient's ataxic gait could be from a posterior fossa (cerebellar) lesion or spinal nerve root involvement. An MRI is better for evaluating posterior fossa lesions, cranial nuclei involvement, and leptomeningeal enhancement. In addition, an MRI of the spine is needed in this patient. (Choice E) Vitamin B12 deficiency would not typically cause cranial nerve involvement and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure.

stem: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her boyfriend after an episode of syncope. The patient says she feels "fine" and wants to go home. She has no prior medical conditions and takes no medications. Her boyfriend states that she is in good health and that she exercises every day, sometimes even "too much" because she wants to be in great shape. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 2 years but does not use alcohol. She smokes marijuana at least twice a week. Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F) blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, pulse is 114/min., and respirations are 16/min. BMI is 17 kg/m2. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and normal jugular venous pressure with no thyromegaly. The lungs are clear on auscultation and heart sounds are normal. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Neurologic examination is within normal limits. Laboratory results are as follows: Complete blood count Hemoglobin 11.0 g/dL Mean corpuscular volume 82 um3 Platelets 180,000/mm3 Leukocytes 8,500/mm3 Serum chemistry Sodium 130 mEq/L Potassium 3.1 mEq/L Chloride 90 mEq/L Bicarbonate 20 mEq/L Blood urea nitrogen 8 mg/dL Creatinine 0.6 mg/dL Glucose 50 mg/dL Urinalysis Specific gravity 1.02 Glucose negative Ketones present Leukocyte esterase negative Nitrites negative Urine pregnancy test results are negative. In the emergency department, 50% dextrose is administered and normal saline infusion is begun. Two hours later, the patient experiences sudden-onset double vision. On repeat examination, she appears mildly lethargic and there is lateral gaze palsy on the right side. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's vision disturbance?
explanation: This underweight woman with multiple electrolyte disturbances, hypoglycemia, and an anion gap metabolic acidosis with urine ketones has evidence of severe malnourishment, likely from anorexia nervosa. She developed double vision with lateral gaze palsy and lethargy after an infusion of dextrose-containing solution, raising concern for Wernicke encephalopathy (WE). WE is a neurologic complication of thiamine deficiency; it classically manifests as the triad of ataxia, encephalopathy (eg, lethargy), and oculomotor dysfunction (eg, nystagmus, gaze palsies), although all 3 signs often do not present together. It is usually associated with long-standing alcohol abuse; however, WE may be caused by any disorder causing chronic malnourishment (eg, anorexia nervosa, hyperemesis gravidarum, post-bariatric surgery). Iatrogenic WE can be precipitated in malnourished patients by the administration of dextrose, which depletes the last remaining stores of thiamine (a cofactor for enzymes involved in glucose metabolism). Most physicians are aware of the need to give thiamine with dextrose in patients with chronic alcohol use; however, there is less awareness regarding thiamine administration with dextrose for other at-risk populations. (Choice A) Magnesium deficiency may cause hypokalemia and vertical nystagmus, but severe deficiency also typically causes hypocalcemia, involuntary movements, seizures, and arrhythmias. It is unlikely to cause a gaze palsy. (Choice B) Marijuana toxicity usually presents with acute mood and thought disturbances in addition to red eyes, tachycardia, elevated blood pressure, and dry mouth. However, it does not usually cause vision disturbances or nystagmus. (Choice C) Refeeding syndrome occurs in a chronically malnourished patient and may cause hypokalemia; however, it also leads to severe hypophosphatemia and causes congestive heart failure, edema, seizures, and rhabdomyolysis. Although this patient is at risk for development of refeeding syndrome, gaze palsies would be unlikely. (Choice D) Starvation (or fasting) ketoacidosis is a normal response to fasting and is commonly seen in patients who are malnourished or even on low-carbohydrate diets. Although this patient does have starvation ketoacidosis, fasting ketosis itself would not cause visual changes.

stem: A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband for new-onset "shaking spells" and high anxiety. She is a yoga teacher and has a history of chronic back pain, generalized anxiety disorder, and dysthymia. Her current medications include venlafaxine, ibuprofen, and tramadol. Her husband says that she recently began taking St. John's wort for depression. Her temperature is 38.3 C (101 F), blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg, and pulse is 144/min. On examination, her voice is tremulous, and there are tremors in her lower extremities. The patient is flushed and diaphoretic. Lower-extremity and ocular clonus is present. Mild rigidity is noted in the lower extremities. Left foot and patellar deep-tendon reflexes are 4+ and 3+, respectively. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This patient exhibits signs and symptoms consistent with serotonin syndrome, a potentially dangerous condition associated with excess serotonergic activity in the central nervous system. Serotonin syndrome is usually caused by inadvertent interactions between drugs, therapeutic use of multiple serotonergic agents, or overdose on serotonergic medications. This patient is taking multiple medications with serotonergic activity, including St. John's wort, venlafaxine (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), and tramadol. No tests confirm the diagnosis of serotonin syndrome, which is made based on medication history and clinical findings. Symptoms include a classic triad of mental status changes (eg, anxiety, delirium, confusion, restlessness), autonomic dysregulation (eg, diaphoresis, tachycardia, hypertension, hyperthermia, diarrhea, mydriasis), and neuromuscular hyperactivity (eg, hyperreflexia, tremor, rigidity, myoclonus, ocular clonus, bilateral Babinski signs). First-line treatment includes removal of precipitating drugs, supportive care (eg, hydration), and benzodiazepines. Failure of symptoms to resolve or onset of more severe symptoms (eg, hyperthermia, disorientation) may require the use of cyproheptadine, a serotonin antagonist. (Choices A and D) If the diagnosis is unclear and symptoms are severe, CT scan can be helpful to evaluate for intracranial bleeding or mass, and lumbar puncture can help rule out meningitis. However, this patient's presentation is highly suggestive of serotonin syndrome, and further diagnostic procedures are not necessary at this time. (Choice B) Electroencephalogram (EEG) is typically used to determine whether seizure activity is occurring. During seizure activity, the EEG typically displays a characteristic synchronous spike-and-wave pattern followed by postictal suppression. Seizure activity involves episodes of tonic-clonic movements followed by a postictal state, but this patient has no tonic movements associated with her clonus and does not appear postictal, lowering clinical suspicion for seizures. (Choice E) No laboratory tests confirm the diagnosis of serotonin syndrome, as serum serotonin levels do not correlate with clinical findings in this condition. Checking serotonin levels would be indicated in a condition such as carcinoid syndrome.

stem: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to right-sided numbness and weakness. The patient says his right side felt numb when he awoke at 5:00 AM, and he was unable to get out of bed due to right arm and leg weakness. The patient called an ambulance and arrived at the emergency department within 45 minutes. He was feeling well with no symptoms when he went to bed last night at 10:00 PM and does not know when his symptoms began. The patient has never had similar symptoms and has no headache, head trauma, fever, or chills. Medical conditions include hypertension and hyperlipidemia, but the patient is nonadherent with medical care and has not seen his primary care physician for the past several years. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Temperature is 36.5 C (97.7 F), blood pressure is 202/104 mm Hg, and pulse is 84/min and regular. The patient is alert but has frequent word-finding difficulty. Right facial droop is present. Motor strength and sensation to pinprick are decreased in the right upper and lower extremities. Babinski reflex is present on the right. Bedside swallow assessment shows no signs of aspiration. Noncontrast CT scan of the head reveals no evidence of subarachnoid or intracerebral hemorrhage. Blood cell counts, serum chemistry studies, and coagulation tests are within normal limits. Blood glucose is 120 mg/dL. An ECG shows sinus rhythm with no acute ischemic changes, and chest radiograph is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
choice_a: Aspirin, clopidogrel, and an intravenous antihypertensive
choice_c: Aspirin and evaluation for mechanical thrombectomy
choice_d: Intravenous antihypertensive followed by thrombolytic therapy
explanation: This patient with new focal weakness and head CT scan without evidence of intracranial or subarachnoid hemorrhage has experienced an acute ischemic cerebrovascular accident (CVA). First-line therapy for eligible patients is intravenous thrombolytic therapy (eg, alteplase); however, treatment must be initiated within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. If timing of CVA is unknown, time of onset is when the patient was at last known normal neurologic function (eg, 10:00 PM for this patient). Those outside the 4.5-hour window, such as this patient, are not candidates for thrombolytic therapy (Choices D and E). Mechanical thrombectomy is indicated in those with a large artery occlusion in the anterior circulation and persistent neurologic defects. It can be performed regardless of alteplase administration and should not be delayed to evaluate response to thrombolysis. Thrombectomy must be initiated within the first 24 hours of last known normal status. Therefore, this patient should undergo further evaluation with a CT or MR angiography. Aspirin reduces the risk of recurrent ischemic strokes and should be given within 24-48 hours; however, it should be withheld for 24 hours in patients who undergo thrombolysis. Blood pressure (BP) management is guided by the administration of thrombolytic therapy. In patients who are not candidates for thrombolytic therapy or thrombectomy, permissive hypertension is allowed to maintain perfusion to the ischemic brain. These patients are treated only for extremely elevated BP (systolic BP >220 mm Hg or diastolic BP >120 mm Hg) or if active coronary artery disease, heart failure, aortic dissection, hypertensive encephalopathy, acute renal failure, or preeclampsia/eclampsia are present. Extremely elevated BP is lowered by no more than 15% in the first 24 hours, typically with intravenous antihypertensive agents. Patients who undergo thrombolysis should have BP lowered to <185/110 mm Hg before therapy and maintained at <180/105 mm Hg for at least 24 hours after administration. (Choices A and B) This patient is not a candidate for thrombolytic therapy and he has no indications for acute blood pressure lowering. In addition, the combination of aspirin and clopidogrel has been shown to increase bleeding risk without improving outcomes in a primary stroke and is not recommended.

stem: A 78-year-old woman who resides in an assisted living facility is brought to the emergency department after having a tonic-clonic seizure. Her caretakers state that the patient became mildly confused and had a headache yesterday. Earlier today, the patient had involuntary shaking of her right upper and lower extremities followed by a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The patient's family reports that she has not had any sick contacts or recent travel. She has no cough, shortness of breath, diarrhea, or urinary symptoms. Her other medical problems include hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient has no known allergies. Her temperature is 38.1 C (100.8 F), blood pressure is 140/88 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min and regular, respirations are 13/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The general physical examination is unremarkable. On neurologic examination, the patient appears obtunded and does not follow commands. On manual motor testing, she is able to localize to pain bilaterally and to withdraw her lower extremities to pain. A non-contrast head CT shows no mass, bleeding, or parenchymal abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows no infiltrates. Urinalysis shows clear urine, negative nitrites, negative leukocyte esterase, 5-10 leukocytes/hpf, and few bacteria. A lumbar puncture is attempted but is unsuccessful. Intravenous vancomycin, ampicillin, and ceftriaxone are administered. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
choice_d: Perform MRI of the brain with and without gadolinium
explanation: This elderly patient with fever, mental status changes, and focal seizures, has possible herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis, the most common cause of fatal encephalitis. HSV encephalitis is seen more frequently in the immunocompromised and the elderly (age >70). It is likely due to viral reactivation of previous latent HSV-1 infection. Patients typically have headache, fever, and possible seizures. Diagnosis is confirmed by HSV polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF); this test is 98% sensitive and 94%-100% specific. However, patients with suspected viral encephalitis should be empirically treated with intravenous (IV) acyclovir while awaiting the results of investigations. Acyclovir halts viral replication and can prevent central nervous system damage; treatment delay can lead to significant neurologic complications. CSF HSV PCR test results are not significantly altered, even if acyclovir is given for 7 days. In addition to receiving acyclovir, this patient should continue to be empirically treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics against organisms that can also cause encephalitis/meningitis. (Choice B) In patients with suspected or confirmed pneumococcal meningitis treated with dexamethasone (which may impact vancomycin penetration into CSF), rifampin can be added to vancomycin and ceftriaxone if the organism shows intermediate susceptibility to ceftriaxone and cefotaxime. However, this patient is not on dexamethasone therapy. (Choice C) Bedside electroencephalogram (EEG) monitoring is usually indicated to rule out non-convulsive status epilepticus, which can sometimes be caused by HSV encephalitis. This patient may need EEG monitoring, but IV acyclovir should be empirically started first in order to avoid treatment delay. (Choice D) Brain MRI with/without gadolinium helps to identify acute ischemic stroke in patients with mental status changes. New focal seizures occur in <5% of acute strokes. However, this patient's negative non-contrast head CT obtained a day after the onset of symptoms makes stroke less likely. Brain MRI can also identify areas of enhancement, which can suggest an infectious etiology. Acyclovir should be started before obtaining a brain MRI to avoid treatment delay. (Choice E) Patients with impaired cellular immunity (eg, due to lymphoma or cytotoxic chemotherapy) who also have meningitis should be treated with vancomycin, ampicillin, and either cefepime or meropenem to ensure antibiotic coverage against Listeria monocytogenes and gram-negative bacilli such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Similarly, patients who have healthcare-acquired meningitis (eg, in the presence of ventricular drain, head trauma, or recent neurosurgery) should receive cefepime or ceftazidime or meropenem in addition to vancomycin.

stem: A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with 2 days of mild right eye pain worsened by eye movement. She also describes a persistent black spot in the center of her vision. She has no recent respiratory infection, fever, or headache. On examination, there is no eye redness or exudate. Funduscopic examination shows mild hyperemia of the right optic disk. MRI of the head shows several scattered ovoid-shaped, periventricular white matter lesions. Which of the following is the best initial treatment for this patient?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with optic neuritis, an inflammatory demyelinating condition of the optic nerve leading to acute visual loss. Optic neuritis is likely immune mediated and typically presents with acute monocular vision loss over a period of hours to days, eye pain, central scotoma, and loss of color vision out of proportion to loss of visual acuity. Examination can show afferent pupillary defect, hyperemia/swelling of the optic disk, and blurring of disk margins with distended veins. Optic neuritis is frequently associated with multiple sclerosis (MS). Approximately 15%-20% of MS patients initially present with optic neuritis, and nearly 50% develop it during the course of their illness. MRI of the brain and orbits with gadolinium can show optic nerve inflammation and characteristic findings of MS, including ovoid-shaped periventricular white matter lesions that are >3 mm. In general, oral and intravenous corticosteroids are considered equally efficacious for the treatment of acute MS attacks. However, intravenous methylprednisolone is preferred in patients with acute optic neuritis as oral therapy is associated with increased risk of recurrent optic neuritis (Choice D). (Choice A) Aspirin is given for atherosclerotic vascular disease, which is unlikely in this young patient. (Choice C) Intravitreal vascular endothelial growth factor is used for the treatment of retinal vein occlusions and macular degeneration. MRI would not show periventricular white matter lesions in these patients. (Choice E) Topical pilocarpine can lower intraocular pressure in acute angle-closure glaucoma. Patients typically develop the acute onset of decreased vision, halos around lights, headache, severe eye pain, and nausea/vomiting. Examination can show conjunctival erythema, corneal edema, and a mid-dilated pupil reacting poorly to light. MRI usually does not show abnormal findings, as seen in this patient.

stem: A 60-year-old right-handed woman with a history of breast cancer with known spine metastasis comes to the emergency department because of headaches and mild left arm weakness. The headaches started 1 month ago and have progressively gotten worse. They occur in the right orbitofrontal region, are sharp in quality, fluctuate in intensity, and have recently been waking her from sleep. She noticed 2 weeks ago that her left arm was weaker than usual. She has taken ibuprofen, with only slight improvement of the headaches. Her temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 90/min. Neurologic examination shows a slight left lower facial palsy and a pronator drift in the left upper extremity. Reflexes are 3+ on the left side of the body, with an ipsilateral Babinski sign. The rest of the neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Basic blood work is normal. An MRI of the brain with and without gadolinium shows a single ring-enhancing lesion with mild surrounding vasogenic edema and mass effect at the grey-white junction in the right frontal lobe that is diffusion-restriction negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
choice_a: Craniotomy with excision biopsy of the right frontal lesion
explanation: In the setting of metastatic breast cancer, a new-onset headache with focal neurologic deficits should prompt a workup for cerebral metastatic disease. On brain MRI with and without gadolinium, metastasis appears as a ring-enhancing lesion with significant reactive vasogenic edema with or without local mass effect. Radiographically, metastasis can mimic an infectious process (e.g., abscess). However, metastasis does not cause restricted diffusion on diffusion-weighted MR sequences, whereas an abscess causes homogeneous restricted diffusion. Also, a cerebral abscess causes fever and peripheral leukocytosis. This patient most likely has a solitary cerebral metastasis and needs to be urgently started on intravenous steroids (e.g., methylprednisolone or dexamethasone) to reduce the surrounding vasogenic edema and mass effect. Reducing the edema might improve the patient's neurologic deficits. (Choice A) Craniotomy with excisional biopsy of the right frontal lesion is appropriate to confirm the diagnosis of metastatic breast cancer. However, the next step in the management of this patient is to reduce the vasogenic edema and mass effect by starting intravenous steroids. (Choice C) Current studies show prophylactic anticonvulsant medications are mainly beneficial in patients with newly diagnosed brain tumors who present with a seizure. Prophylactic anticonvulsants (for 1 week with taper afterwards) are also indicated in patients who have had a craniotomy for brain tumor resection, brain MRI showing acute hemorrhage within the tumor, or significant mass effect/edema in the vicinity of the cortex. Steroids can acutely reduce the edema and greatly reduce the risk of seizure in this patient. (Choice D) A lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the setting of a space-occupying lesion with mass effect and/or midline shift, due to risk of herniation. In addition, this patient's clinical history, brain imaging, and blood work are not suggestive of an infectious process. (Choice E) Whole-brain radiation therapy is indicated in patients with multifocal brain metastases. For solitary metastasis, the treatment of choice is surgical resection.

stem: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with right-sided weakness and slurred speech that started 1 hour ago. He has no headache, double or blurry vision, or loss of consciousness. The patient's past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia, but he does not take any prescription medications. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 170/96 mm Hg, pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 14/min. On examination, he has right lower facial droop, dysarthria, and muscle weakness in his right upper and lower extremities. An immediate non-contrast head CT is obtained showing no abnormalities. Laboratory workup has been sent. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step before administering an intravenous fibrinolytic agent in this patient?
choice_a: Obtain CT angiography of the head and neck
choice_c: Wait for basic metabolic panel results
choice_e: Wait for complete blood count results
explanation: The only immediate laboratory study required prior to administering thrombolytic therapy is a blood glucose level. Hypoglycemia (glucose <60 mg/dL) can result in neuronal injury and present with focal neurologic deficits that mimic stroke; efforts should be made to achieve euglycemia in these patients. (Choice A) CT angiography of the head and neck is strongly recommended during the initial evaluation of stroke if intra-arterial fibrinolysis or mechanical thrombectomy is being considered. However, it should never delay initiation of intravenous thrombolytic therapy. (Choices C, D, and E) Laboratory tests such as a complete blood count and coagulation panel (eg, PT, INR, and aPTT) are necessary in the workup of acute stroke. However, these should not delay thrombolytic therapy unless the patient is on anticoagulation or if there is suspicion for coagulopathy, none of which are present in this patient. Similarly, a basic metabolic panel should be checked but thrombolytic therapy should not be delayed while awaiting results.

stem: A 30-year-old previously healthy man comes to the emergency department due to back pain and difficulty walking. His symptoms began 4 days ago with lower back pain, which he attributed to moving furniture around his apartment. The patient also experienced a tingling sensation in his feet and hands and by the next day had difficulty walking. His weakness has gradually progressed and he has also experienced frequent episodes of palpitations, excessive sweating, and dyspnea. The patient has not travelled recently and reports no recent respiratory or gastrointestinal illness or vaccinations. He takes no medications, drinks alcohol occasionally, and does not use tobacco or illicit drugs. He has had 2 sexual partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. On examination, the patient is alert and cooperative. Bilateral pupils react sluggishly to light and accommodation. His speech is slightly dysarthric with mild weakness of the buccinators. Bilateral upper extremity motor strength is 4/5 with hyporeflexia, and bilateral lower extremity tone is decreased with 3/5 motor strength and areflexia. Vibration and proprioception sensations are reduced in the feet bilaterally. Coordination and gait testing are limited by weakness. There is no spine tenderness or neck rigidity. Which of the following would be most helpful in establishing the diagnosis in this patient?
choice_b: Lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid analysis
explanation: This patient with back pain, paresthesias, symmetric weakness worse in the lower extremities, and hyporeflexia likely has Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS), or acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy. Classic GBS presents as a progressive, symmetric ascending weakness or paralysis, often a few days to a week after a respiratory or gastrointestinal infection (especially Campylobacter jejuni). About one-third of patients have no history of antecedent illness. As the weakness ascends (eg, difficulty walking with 3/5 strength in the lower extremities compared with 4/5 strength in the upper extremities in this patient), bulbar symptoms (eg, ophthalmoplegia, facial diplegia, dysarthria, dysphasia) and respiratory compromise can develop. Back pain can be a presenting feature of GBS as the disease targets primarily the proximal nerves and nerve roots in either the cervical or lumbar spine. Although GBS is primarily a motor polyneuropathy, patients can have mild sensory symptoms such as paresthesias and sensory ataxia. GBS patients also are at risk of developing dysautonomia (eg, tachycardia, diaphoresis, sluggish pupils). Examination shows absent reflexes. Lumbar puncture is indicated in all suspected GBS patients to rule out infectious etiologies and document elevated cerebrospinal protein with a normal cerebrospinal fluid white blood cell count (albuminocytologic dissociation). However, lumbar puncture may not be diagnostic in some GBS patients as it may take up to a week after symptom onset to see the abnormal findings. Nerve conduction study and electromyography are also indicated to confirm the diagnosis and estimate prognosis. Treatment is mainly supportive, with plasma exchange or intravenous immunoglobulin. Current evidence does not recommend corticosteroids as they are not beneficial. Most patients recover within several weeks to months. (Choice A) Acetylcholine receptor antibodies are useful for diagnosing myasthenia gravis, which usually presents with fluctuating muscle weakness and muscular fatigue. However, myasthenia gravis usually does not present as a rapidly ascending weakness. (Choices C and D) The topographical pattern of deficits in this patient (bilateral symptoms) would not be consistent with a focal structural lesion in the brain (eg, stroke or tumor). MRI of the cervical spine would be low yield in this patient as it would not explain the abnormal cranial nerve findings. This patient also does not have upper motor neuron signs (eg, brisk reflexes) to suggest myelopathy. (Choice E) Serum rapid plasma reagin test is used to diagnosis syphilis. Tabes dorsalis (a manifestation of neurosyphilis) can cause sensory ataxia, paresthesias, back pain, and abnormal pupillary response (Argyll-Robertson pupil). However, it does not cause ascending weakness, and Argyll-Robertson pupils accommodate but do not react to light.

stem: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and generalized weakness. She also complains of cough, especially during and after meals. Over the past 3 weeks she has had episodes of blurry vision and difficulty raising her arms above her head and walking up and down stairs. She has no hemoptysis, muscles aches, slurred speech, headaches, numbness, or paresthesias. Her medical history is significant for hypothyroidism and hypertension. There is no family history of malignancy. She is an active smoker with a 20-pack-year history. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has subjective fatigable horizontal binocular diplopia. Her neck flexors and proximal muscles of the upper and lower extremities are 4/5 in strength. Sensory examination and reflex testing are unremarkable. Vital capacity obtained at the bedside is 0.5 L (< 50% of predicted). Complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and chest x-ray are normal. Noncontrast computed tomography scan of the chest shows mild centrilobular emphysema and a 2.6-cm mediastinal mass. There is no regional lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
choice_b: Magnetic resonance imaging of the cervical spine
explanation: This patient's presentation suggests generalized myasthenia gravis (MG). MG is due to autoantibodies blocking acetylcholine receptors. Ocular MG presents with eyelid and ocular muscle weakness. Generalized MG affects ocular muscles with variable involvement of bulbar (eg, dysarthria, dysphagia, fatigable chewing), limb, or respiratory muscles. These symptoms can fluctuate throughout the day but are usually worse later in the day. Weakness and fatigue worsen with exercise, stress, or infection and improve with rest. Diagnosis of MG is confirmed with serology. Acetylcholine receptor (AchR) antibody is present in up to 85% of MG patients. Muscle-specific tyrosine kinase receptor (MuSK) antibodies are present in up to 50% of AchR-antibody-negative patients. MG is also commonly associated with thymic hyperplasia, thymoma, and autoimmune thyroid disease. All MG patients should have thyroid-stimulating hormone measured to evaluate for thyroiditis and chest computed tomography to look for mediastinal mass (thymoma). Once the diagnosis of MG is confirmed via serology or electrophysiology, patients can be treated with symptomatic (eg, pyridostigmine) and/or immune (eg, corticosteroids, intravenous immunoglobulin) therapies. (Choice A) Lumbar puncture can help diagnose multiple sclerosis, Guillain-Barre syndrome, or central nervous system tumor. Multiple sclerosis usually presents with relapsing-remitting episodes of neurologic dysfunction disseminated in space and time. Guillain-Barre syndrome typically presents with ascending weakness, absent deep-tendon reflexes, and mild sensory symptoms after a recent viral illness. Central nervous system tumors (lymphomatous or carcinomatous meningitis) have other symptoms, including headache, nausea, vomiting, mental status changes, focal weakness, radicular pain, or cranial nerve palsies. (Choice B) Brain magnetic resonance imaging is recommended in MG patients who have bulbar symptoms to rule out other pathology. However, cervical spine imaging does not explain this patient's ocular findings. (Choice C) Muscle biopsy can diagnose a myopathy, which can cause symmetrical muscle weakness but not ocular symptoms. (Choice E) Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is a paraneoplastic syndrome most commonly associated with small-cell lung cancer. LEMS presentation can be similar to myasthenia gravis. Both can have ocular symptoms and muscle weakness. In LEMS, deep-tendon reflexes are decreased or absent. However, deep-tendon reflexes and weakness improve with repetitive muscle activation. Voltage-gated calcium channel antibodies confirm the diagnosis. Given this patient's young age and mediastinal (rather than lung) mass, MG is more likely.

stem: A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to right-sided weakness on awakening this morning. The patient has had no headache, nausea, double or blurry vision, or vertigo. Medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Medications include metformin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 168/96 mm Hg, pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 12/min Physical examination reveals a carotid bruit on the left. Neurologic examination shows mild dysarthria, right central facial palsy, and mild right hemiparesis. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm. MRI of the brain reveals multiple acute cortical and subcortical infarcts in the left middle cerebral artery territory, as shown in the image below. CT angiography of the head and neck reveals 80%-90% stenosis at the origin of the left internal carotid artery. Echocardiogram shows mild left atrial enlargement, left ventricular hypertrophy, and left ventricular ejection fraction of 65%. The patient receives low-dose aspirin in the emergency department. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
choice_c: Enoxaparin (therapeutic dose) for the duration of hospitalization
explanation: This patient has evidence of acute left middle cerebral artery ischemic stroke associated with ipsilateral, high-grade carotid stenosis. In addition to medical therapy including aspirin, statin, blood pressure control, and risk modification (eg, glucose control, smoking cessation), he also requires consultation to consider carotid revascularization. Symptomatic patients (ie, transient ischemic attack or ischemic stroke within the distribution of the affected vessel) with a life expectancy of >=5 years and high-grade stenosis (70%-99%) should be offered a carotid endarterectomy (CEA). Post-hoc analysis of pooled data from the North American Symptomatic Carotid Endarterectomy Trial (NASCET) and the European Carotid Surgery Trial (ECST) suggests that CEA within 1-2 weeks of a nondisabling stroke or transient ischemic attack improves outcomes compared with later surgery; very early CEA (<48 hours) is associated with higher risk of recurrent stroke. (Choice A) In very large strokes with associated cerebral edema or hemorrhagic complications, a delay of 4-6 weeks for revascularization is reasonable. However, in most cases, revascularization should be completed within 1-2 weeks. In high-grade stenosis, CEA is preferred to carotid artery stenting due to lower periprocedural mortality and stroke rates. (Choice C) Studies have found no benefit of early anticoagulation in the setting of acute ischemic stroke (whether due to atherosclerotic disease or cardioembolism) due to the significant risk of hemorrhagic transformation. (Choice D) Warfarin is not more beneficial than antiplatelet therapy in atherothrombotic or atherothromboembolic strokes and carries a significant risk of bleeding. (Choice E) Nimodipine is indicated in the treatment of post-aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage to protect against vasospasm. It is not used routinely in ischemic stroke.

stem: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to acute dizziness for 6 hours. The patient awoke this morning with the persistent sensation of "the room spinning around," which becomes worse with head movement. She also has nausea and vomiting, but no headache or vision problems. Nothing seems to relieve her symptoms. Her other medical problems are hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Home medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin. Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg, and pulse is 84/min. On examination, the patient has bidirectional nystagmus. Muscle strength, light touch and pain sensation, and reflexes are normal throughout. The patient's gait is unsteady and she tends to fall toward the right side. Blood sugar is 140 mg/dL and electrolytes are normal. Noncontrast CT scan of the head is normal. ECG reveals normal sinus rhythm. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This patient's presentation of acute, sustained vertigo with bidirectional nystagmus is concerning for cerebellar stroke. Cerebellar stroke can be difficult to distinguish from other causes of vertigo, particularly vestibular neuritis. Up to 25% of patients age >50 who come to the emergency department with acute-onset isolated vertigo have cerebellar infarction rather than vestibular neuritis. Characteristics of nystagmus can help distinguish central from peripheral causes of vertigo: Peripheral disease (eg, vestibular neuritis, Meniere disease) causes a suppressible nystagmus that does not reverse direction; it beats away from the lesion. Central disease (eg, cerebellar stroke, multiple sclerosis) causes a nonsuppressible nystagmus that can reverse direction (eg, bidirectional); it often beats toward the lesion. Features suggestive of cerebellar stroke include limb ataxia, inability to ambulate, falling/nystagmus to the side of the lesion, and symptoms persisting for >=72 hours. In addition to neurologic abnormalities (eg, dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesia), the presence of persistent hiccups is supportive. Cerebellar stroke is more common in elderly patients with cardiovascular risk factors. Neuroimaging should be obtained in patients with vertigo if there are risk factors for stroke, new headache or neurologic deficits, or features consistent with a central lesion. MRI and MR angiography are the preferred studies given their high sensitivity/specificity in detecting acute cerebellar infarction and posterior circulation occlusion, respectively. CT scan is less sensitive in detecting posterior fossa abnormalities and may be normal within the initial hours of stroke onset. (Choice A) Audiometry has limited utility in the evaluation of vertigo but may be used to assess hearing loss in patients with suspected Meniere disease or vestibular schwannoma. (Choice B) Carotid ultrasound is of limited use in this patient with cerebellar/posterior circulation signs (eg, vertigo, nystagmus, ataxia). (Choice C) The Epley maneuver is a particle-repositioning maneuver that can be used to treat benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). Although BPPV may present with nystagmus and vertigo provoked by head movement, nystagmus is typically unidirectional rather than bidirectional, symptoms are typically brief (usually seconds), and ataxia is usually absent. (Choice E) Reassurance and short-term use of antihistamines such as meclizine may be considered for symptomatic treatment of peripheral vertigo (eg, vestibular neuritis). However, this patient has risk factors and clinical findings consistent with cerebellar stroke that must be excluded first.

stem: A 32-year-old woman with a history of migraine headaches comes to the emergency department with severe left-sided headache and nausea that started 3 hours ago. Earlier in the morning she had blurry vision and saw halos around lights. She took ibuprofen an hour ago but vomited shortly afterward. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The patient feels uncomfortable when her eyes are examined with a flashlight. The pupils are equal and reactive. Muscle strength and tone are normal and deep-tendon reflexes are symmetrical. She is treated with intravenous metoclopramide. One hour later, she complains of neck pain. Physical examination shows sustained contraction of the posterior neck muscles associated with neck extension and tenderness. What is the best next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This patient has likely developed metoclopramide-induced acute dystonia. Metoclopramide is a dopamine receptor antagonist that also blocks serotonin receptors at higher doses. The drug is often used in the emergency department as monotherapy for acute migraine associated with nausea/vomiting. It may also be effective for diabetic gastroparesis. Potential side effects include akathisia, dystonia, and tardive dyskinesia. Acute dystonia presents with sustained muscular contractions resulting in twisting or abnormal postures (eg, torticollis, retrocollis, oculogyric crisis). Retrocollis is characterized by sustained contraction of the posterior neck muscles resulting in neck extension and pain, as seen in this patient. Patients with suspected drug-induced dystonia should stop the offending agent. Treatment also involves anticholinergics (eg, benztropine, trihexyphenidyl) or agents with both anticholinergic and antihistamine effects (eg, diphenhydramine). These treatments should be started at low doses with slow titration to achieve improvement. They should also be tapered off gradually due to the risk of withdrawal side effects. (Choice A) Haloperidol can control acute agitation, but it is also a dopamine receptor blocker that can further exacerbate extrapyramidal symptoms. (Choice C) Lumbar puncture can diagnose meningitis, but this patient's lack of fever makes the diagnosis unlikely. (Choice D) Noncontrast head CT scan can diagnose subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), which usually presents as a sudden, severe ("thunderclap") headache. This patient's headache was preceded by visual symptoms, which is more typical of migraine with aura. Although meningismus is present in 35% of patients with SAH, this patient's sustained posterior neck extension is more consistent with retrocollis. (Choice E) Subcutaneous sumatriptan may be effective for abortive migraine treatment, but it would not address this patient's acute dystonia.

stem: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of mild headache, confusion, and right-sided upper extremity weakness for the last 2 days. The patient is accompanied by his wife, who provides most of the history. The patient was working in his garden 2 days ago when he developed a headache. He thought nothing of it since he was working outdoors on a hot and humid summer day. Over the next 24-hours, the patient became lethargic and developed right-sided weakness. He has not traveled recently and denies insect bites, sick contacts, or flu-like symptoms. His other medical problems include a history of ischemic stroke without residual neurologic deficits, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and non-paralytic polio as a child. His medications include aspirin, simvastatin, and lisinopril. His temperature is 38.1 C (100.5 F), blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, pulse is 101/min, and respirations are 16/min Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. His general physical examination is unremarkable. On neurological examination, he is obtunded and does not follow commands. There are no obvious cranial nerve deficits. He is able to localize briskly to noxious stimuli with the left arm, but he does not move the right arm. He is able to withdraw briskly to noxious stimuli in the lower extremities (left > right). The sensory examination is unreliable. Reflexes are 2+ on the left side of the body, but absent on the right side. Plantar responses are downgoing bilaterally. Superficial abdominal reflexes are present. Rectal tone is normal. Non-contrast CT scan of the head showed no bleeding or masses. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient's presentation is suggestive of encephalomyelitis, most likely due to the mosquito-borne West Nile virus. The incidence is highest during the mosquito season in the summer months, especially when the weather is humid. Most patients are asymptomatic or only develop fever. Encephalitis associated with acute asymmetric flaccid paralysis or extrapyramidal symptoms is highly suggestive of West Nile virus infection. The West Nile virus typically causes anterior horn cell injury (poliomyelitis) rather than a transverse leukomyelitis. Therefore, patients will have sparing of the ascending (i.e., pain, temperature, vibration, and proprioception) and descending (i.e., pyramidal and extra-pyramidal motor system and autonomics) white matter fibers. Diagnosis is usually confirmed with positive IgM serology for the virus in patients with only fever. Patients with CNS symptoms should undergo lumbar puncture to rule out other etiologies and confirm diagnosis with West Nile IgM antibody titer. Treatment involves mainly supportive care, but preventative mosquito control programs are sometimes effective. (Choice A) This patient has downgoing plantar reflexes, low-grade fever, and worsening mental status changes. This combination makes an ischemic stroke highly unlikely. (Choice B) Enteroviruses commonly cause viral meningitis in the summer and early fall and present with severe headache, neck stiffness, photophobia, and low-grade fever. However, enteroviral meningitis does not usually cause mental status changes, or flaccid paralysis as seen in this patient. (Choice C) Guillain-Barre syndrome usually presents with progressive and symmetrical ascending paralysis, paresthesias, decreased to absent reflexes, and possible respiratory distress. This patient's asymmetrical lower extremity symptoms/signs make this less likely. (Choice D) Post-polio syndrome can be seen in patients with a history of paralytic polio who develop worsening of their previous weakness later in life (> age 50) due to age related drop out of existing large motor units. Patients typically present with progressive weakness, fatigue, and muscle or joint pain. The syndrome usually does not present with fever, mental status changes, headache, or seizures.

stem: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency room because of "head spinning" for the last 4 hours. He states that he has severe difficulty with his balance and feels like he is leaning to the right. He denies headache, double vision, muscle weakness, nausea, or vomiting. His past medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and mild intermittent asthma. He had a mild upper respiratory infection three weeks ago with a persistent sore throat until last week. His daily medications include glyburide, aspirin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. He is an ex-smoker with a 35 pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 36.7 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 155/92 mm Hg, and pulse is 87/min with regular rhythm. On neurological examination, he is alert and cooperative. Cranial nerve examination reveals an up-beat torsional jerk nystagmus. Mild dysmetria is present on the right upon the finger-to-nose test. His fingerstick glucose is 75 mg/dL. A non-contrast head CT shows no intracranial bleeding and is otherwise unremarkable. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
choice_a: Admit for MRI of the brain
choice_b: Give oral glucose and stop glyburide
choice_d: Prescribe meclizine and schedule outpatient follow-up
explanation: This patient's clinical presentation is consistent with vertigo, likely due to a central cause. Vertigo is classified as either central or peripheral. Peripheral vertigo usually presents with contralateral nystagmus from the affected side that worsens with gaze opposite the lesion and improves with gaze towards the lesion. There is usually a latency period before symptom onset that occurs for only a brief period. Central vertigo presents with less vertigo and more gait disturbances, disequilibrium, vertical and/or torsional nystagmus, and possible various associated neurological symptoms. There is usually no latency period before the onset of nystagmus. This patient's difficulty with walking favors a more central etiology of the vertigo and should be evaluated with MRI with diffusion protocol for possible acute stroke. (Choice B) A blood glucose of 75 mg/dL is generally not low enough to explain the patient's focal neurological deficits. A serum blood glucose <50 mg/dL usually causes focal neurological deficits. (Choice C) Vestibular neuronitis (second most common cause of peripheral vertigo) is usually due to herpes virus and presents with sudden vertigo lasting several days. Methylprednisolone hastens recovery, but acyclovir has limited efficacy in improving symptoms. This patient's symptoms are more consistent with central vertigo. (Choice D) Meclizine is appropriate for patients with suspected BPPV, but this patient's nystagmus and dysmetria are more concerning for central vertigo and should be evaluated with urgent brain MRI. (Choice E) Epley's maneuver (vestibular exercises) is a bedside procedure for BPPV and involves moving the patient's head in various directions to reposition the dislodged otolith in the semicircular canals. However, these maneuvers are less effective for central vertigo.

stem: A 38-year-old woman comes to the emergency department following an episode of loss of consciousness. She was washing the dishes when she became light-headed, weak, and developed blurry vision. The patient reportedly became limp, passed out on the kitchen floor, and had a few body jerks seconds after falling. She regained consciousness in 3-5 minutes and was not confused or disoriented afterwards. She did not have any tongue biting, headache, palpitations, shortness of breath, or chest pain. Her medical history is significant for hypertension and diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her medications include lisinopril, amlodipine, and chlorthalidone. The patient's blood pressure is 112/76 mm Hg and heart rate is 89/min Chest auscultation reveals no abnormalities. There are no signs of trauma or neurologic deficits. Electrocardiogram is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This patient is presenting with convulsive syncope. Brief myoclonic activity associated with syncope is due to cerebral hypoperfusion and can commonly be mistaken for seizure. Features that are more suggestive of seizure include a post-ictal state, tongue biting, head/eye turning to one side, and hypersalivation. The evaluation of syncope should begin with a careful history, physical examination (including orthostatic vital signs), and an electrocardiogram (ECG), as this will identify a specific cause in about 60% of cases. This patient's presentation of syncope in the setting of prolonged standing (eg, washing the dishes) and use of multiple antihypertensive medications (eg, a calcium channel blocker and a diuretic) raises suspicion for orthostatic hypotension; another possibility is vasovagal syncope. The most appropriate next step in management is to check orthostatic vital signs. Additional testing should be based on the initial clinical evaluation. (Choices A and B) Brain imaging, electroencephalogram, and carotid Doppler are rarely useful unless there is concern for a non-syncopal cause of transient loss of consciousness (eg, seizure, cerebrovascular disease). This patient's lack of post-ictal confusion or tongue biting and normal neurologic examination make a non-syncopal cause of transient loss of consciousness less likely. (Choice C) An echocardiogram should be performed in patients suspected of having structural heart disease. However, it would be of limited value in this patient as her syncope did not occur in the setting of physical exertion and her ECG and cardiovascular examination were normal. (Choice E) Tilt-table testing can be useful for diagnosing vasovagal syncope (sensitivity 26%-80%, specificity 90%), but it is usually reserved for patients with atypical presentations, recurrent syncopal episodes after cardiovascular etiologies have been excluded, or after a single unexplained syncopal episode when the diagnosis must be excluded (eg, high risk of physical harm or occupational hazard).

stem: A 43-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to a 2-hour history of vertigo, occipital headache, and lip numbness. She reports having seen "floating lights" earlier, but her vision was not compromised. The patient has a history of migraine headaches without aura. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Current medications include a combination estrogen-progestin oral contraceptive. Blood pressure is 130/77 mm Hg and pulse is 98/min. Neurologic examination shows mild dysarthria but is otherwise normal. MRI of the brain without contrast shows no acute intracranial abnormality. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
choice_c: Obtain MR angiogram of the head and neck
explanation: This patient with a history of migraine who presents with an occipital headache, brainstem symptoms, and a normal brain MRI is likely experiencing a migraine with brainstem aura (MBA; previously known as a basilar-type migraine). MBA is a rare subset of migraine characterized by aura with brainstem symptoms (eg, vertigo, dysarthria, ataxia) without motor weakness. It is most common in women with a history of migraine. Diagnosis requires the presence of >2 basilar aura symptoms (shown in the table) that are fully reversible. Occipital headaches may suggest the diagnosis but are not always present. The symptoms of MBA can mimic dysfunction of the posterior cerebral circulation; differential diagnosis includes transient ischemic attack and basilar aneurysm, as well as temporal lobe epilepsy and benign paroxysmal positional vertigo. As a result, most patients require MRI of the brain and MR angiography of the head and neck to rule out posterior vascular lesions. After vascular lesions have been ruled out, patients can be treated with antiemetics and non-vasoconstricting agents (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs). Triptans (eg, sumatriptan), beta blockers, and ergotamine derivatives are contraindicated in MBA because they may lead to vasoconstriction and ischemia of the vertebral-basilar system (Choice A). Verapamil is preferred for chronic prevention (Choice E); alternatives include lamotrigine, amitriptyline, and topiramate. (Choice B) Oral contraceptives should be discontinued in patients who experience migraine with aura. However, this patient first warrants additional imaging due to the potentially devastating complications of missed neurovascular disease. (Choice D) Electroencephalogram should be considered to exclude seizure in a patient experiencing MBA with altered mentation, which is not seen in this case.
