stem: A 76-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to persistent back pain for the last 2 weeks. Over the last several days he has also had increasing difficulty walking. The patient was diagnosed with locally advanced prostate cancer a year ago and was treated with radiation therapy. His other medical problems include type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, and pulse is 70/min. Neurological examination shows mild spastic paraparesis of the lower extremities. Laboratory values show serum creatinine of 2.1 mg/dL and calcium of 9.8 mg/dL. MRI of the spine reveals a discrete epidural mass at the T8-T9 levels. There is surrounding spinal cord edema. In addition to intravenous corticosteroids, which of the following would be most helpful to improve mobility in this patient?
explanation: This patient has neoplastic epidural spinal cord compression likely due to metastatic prostate cancer. His presentation of back pain followed by progressive spastic lower extremity paraparesis and an epidural mass with spinal cord edema is characteristic. Intravenous glucocorticoids (eg, dexamethasone) are usually given to patients with neoplastic cord compression and severe neurologic deficits, although evidence of improved neurologic outcomes is limited. Definitive therapy with spinal surgery and/or radiation therapy increases the likelihood that the patient will regain normal ambulation; choice of therapy depends on the patient's characteristics. Those with an unstable spine, limited disease burden, and favorable prognosis can benefit from spinal surgery (eg, tumor resection, spine stabilization) followed by radiation therapy as these patients have a higher likelihood of regaining neurologic function. Radiation therapy alone can be considered in patients with a stable spine and radiosensitive neoplasm (eg, breast cancer, lymphoma, multiple myeloma) or as palliative therapy in those with a poor prognosis and limited life expectancy. (Choices A, D, and E) Androgen deprivation therapy with leuprolide can be used to treat metastatic prostate cancer, and intravenous chemotherapy (eg, taxanes) can be considered in patients with castrate-resistant prostate cancer. Parenteral bisphosphonates such as pamidronate can be useful in treating bone pain and delaying pathologic fractures in patients with castrate-resistant prostate cancer and bone metastases. Pamidronate should be used very cautiously in those with renal insufficiency. This patient's spinal cord compression is a neurologic emergency, and he should first be evaluated for definitive spinal surgery to help prevent permanent disability before considering any of these therapies. (Choice C) Intrathecal chemotherapy is used to treat leptomeningeal (dura, arachnoid, and pia mater) metastases due to certain solid and hematologic malignancies (eg, breast, lymphoma, leukemia among others). This patient has extrinsic cord compression from an epidural mass, not leptomeningeal metastases. In addition, leptomeningeal spread of prostate cancer is extremely rare, and it is not treated with intrathecal chemotherapy.

stem: A 57-year-old woman with known myasthenia gravis is brought to the emergency department after 2 weeks of progressively worsening weakness in her arms and legs, fatigue, and intermittent shortness of breath. She could not eat breakfast today due to difficulty swallowing. Her only other medical problem is hypertension, and her medications include pyridostigmine, olmesartan, and chlorthalidone. The patient's blood pressure is 122/72 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination shows clear lung fields and normal first and second heart sounds. There is no nasal flaring or usage of accessory respiratory muscles. There is mild proximal weakness (4/5) in the arms and legs. Pinprick and light touch sensations are intact. Her vital capacity is 25 mL/kg. Laboratory results include serum potassium of 3.8 mEq/L and serum creatinine of 0.8 mg/dL. Her chest x-ray is clear. Which of the following is the most appropriate way to monitor this patient's respiratory status?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with myasthenic crisis, defined as severe weakness from myasthenia gravis requiring intubation. Myasthenic crisis is usually due to weakness of the respiratory muscles but can also present as severe oropharyngeal weakness resulting in dysphagia and aspiration. The common precipitants are infection and surgery (Table); however, it can also present as a progression of myasthenia gravis. Patients should be monitored in the intensive care unit with respiratory status checks every 2-4 hours using vital capacity (VC) and maximal inspiratory force (MIF). Both VC and MIF should be interpreted in combination as neither is superior to the other. Patients require intubation for VC <20 mL/kg or MIF >-30 cm H2O (eg, 0 to -30). Anticholinesterase inhibitors should be stopped temporarily while the patient is on mechanical ventilation to minimize secretions. Rapid treatment involves plasmapheresis or intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) in addition to high-dose glucocorticoids (prednisone 60-80 mg/day) due to the short-lived therapeutic effect of plasmapheresis and IVIG. Patients who cannot tolerate glucocorticoids can be started on azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, or cyclosporine. Weaning and extubation are considered in patients with improved muscle strength (eg, ability to lift head off bed, VC >20 mL/kg. MIF <-30 cm H2O). (Choices A, C, D, and E) Arterial PCO2, oxygen saturation, peak expiratory flow rate, and respiratory rate are not good predictors of impending respiratory failure as they may not show marked abnormalities until late stages.

stem: A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department with right foot pain. Three days ago, he noticed that he was tripping and falling frequently. He initially experienced pain and tingling in his right lower leg that progressively turned into weakness 24 hours later. Three months ago, he experienced similar pain and weakness in his left hand. His past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and lumbar degenerative disk disease. His blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg and pulse is 90/min. On physical examination, he has palpatory tenderness along the lumbar spine and trophic skin changes with stasis dermatitis in the lower extremities. Cranial nerve examination is unremarkable. Strength is 4/5 in the left hand and 3/5 in the right foot. Motor examination is normal in all other muscle groups. There is absence of pain and temperature sensation up to the knees with preserved vibration and proprioception. Reflexes are normal in the upper extremities and the knees but are absent at the ankles bilaterally. He has a steppage gait. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient with a history of diabetes mellitus presents with complaints of abrupt onset of asymmetric, multiple peripheral neuropathies suggestive of mononeuritis multiplex. Mononeuritis multiplex is a painful, asymmetrical, sensory and motor peripheral neuropathy. It affects 2 or more nerves in different parts of the body and is most common in patients with vasculitides, connective tissue diseases, or systemic disorders such as diabetes mellitus. Multiple long nerves (eg, sciatic, peroneal, tibial, radial) in random areas of the body are commonly affected first. As the disease progresses, neuropathy can become more confluent and symmetrical. Patients typically present with complaints of pain, numbness, dysesthesias, or loss of reflexes. Some patients may initially present with foot drop (steppage or foot-slapping gait) or wrist drop. Clinical symptoms are sufficient to make the diagnosis. However, nerve biopsy (which shows epineurial perivascular inflammation) or electrodiagnostic studies can be performed if there is insufficient evidence. Treatment includes controlling the primary disease process. In patients who remain symptomatic despite adequate control of primary disease, over-the-counter analgesics, tricyclic antidepressants, and anticonvulsant drugs (eg, gabapentin) can be used. Most patients recover without long-term consequences, but some may have muscle wasting and irreversible damage due to nerve infarction. (Choice A) Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that causes destruction of the upper and lower motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord. Sensory symptoms are absent. (Choice B) L5 radiculopathy is the most common lumbosacral radiculopathy. Patients present with back pain that radiates down the lateral surface of the leg into the foot. Hand symptoms are not seen in L5 radiculopathy. (Choice C) Patients with lacunar strokes may present with sensory or motor symptoms, hemiparesis, or dysarthria. This patient has predominantly lower motor neuron signs (ie, absent reflexes). (Choice E) Multiple sclerosis usually occurs in patients age 15-50 years. Patients commonly present with 2 or more distinct episodes of central nervous system dysfunction with partial or complete resolution. Multiple sclerosis does not affect the peripheral nervous system.

stem: A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension is brought to the emergency department for acute onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech, which started an hour ago. He takes no prescription medications and has no history of bleeding. The patient's blood pressure is 170/96 mm Hg. On examination, he has right lower facial droop, dysarthria, and diminished strength in his right upper and lower extremities. A non-contrast head CT is negative. His finger stick blood glucose is 90 mg/dL. Intravenous tissue plasminogen activator is administered. Assuming this patient's symptoms do not resolve rapidly, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
choice_a: Aspirin after 24 hours and subcutaneous low-dose enoxaparin now
choice_b: Aspirin now and subcutaneous low-dose enoxaparin after 24 hours
choice_c: Both aspirin and subcutaneous low-dose enoxaparin after 24 hours
choice_d: Both aspirin and subcutaneous low-dose enoxaparin now
explanation: Venous thromboembolism (VTE) is responsible for 13%-25% of early deaths after stroke and typically occurs 2-4 weeks after stroke onset. This patient has an acute ischemic stroke and appropriately received tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) but still has impaired mobility, putting him at higher risk for VTE. Although he would benefit from anticoagulants and aspirin, they are not to be given <24 hours after starting tPA due to an increased risk of symptomatic intracranial hemorrhage (Choices A, B, and D). After 24 hours, patients should typically receive a follow-up neuroimaging study (eg, head CT, brain MRI) to rule out intracranial hemorrhage prior to starting anticoagulants or aspirin. Thigh-length intermittent pneumatic compression devices are generally recommended at presentation in these patients. Studies show that low-dose enoxaparin has the highest benefit-to-risk ratio for preventing VTE and avoiding major intracranial/extracranial hemorrhage, in comparison to high-dose enoxaparin and unfractionated heparin. Educational objective: In patients with acute ischemic stroke, aspirin and anticoagulation (for venous thromboembolism prophylaxis) should not be started within 24 hours of initiating tissue plasminogen activator and should generally be preceded by neuroimaging to rule out intracranial hemorrhage.

stem: A 27-year-old man comes to the emergency department with severe right eye pain. Over the last 3 days, he has had several episodes of "unbearable" eye pain that lasts 30-40 minutes and then resolves completely. He would not sit down for a physical examination and paces around the room in pain. His right eye shows conjunctival injection with a constricted pupil. There is notable right-sided excessive lacrimation and rhinorrhea. Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with cluster headache (Table). Cluster headache is more common in men, and the diagnosis is suggested when the patient has 5 or more severe headache attacks with 1 or more ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (eg, ptosis, miosis, lacrimation, conjunctival injection, rhinorrhea, nasal congestion). Patients are usually agitated or restless, which can help differentiate cluster headache from migraine. Brain MRI, even in the setting of a typical presentation, is usually obtained during the initial evaluation to exclude intracranial abnormalities. Current guidelines recommend 100% oxygen (12 L/min for 15 min) and/or subcutaneous sumatriptan as a first-line treatment for acute cluster headache. Preventive therapy should also be promptly initiated. Verapamil is the preferred preventive treatment, sometimes accompanied by a short course of oral corticosteroids. (Choices A and E) Acute angle-closure glaucoma (ACG) may present with severe headache, eye pain, and conjunctival injection; however, this patient's young age and absence of other features (eg, decreased vision, nausea/vomiting, poorly reactive mid-dilated pupil) make the diagnosis unlikely. ACG warrants emergent referral to an ophthalmologist. Patients who cannot be seen by a specialist within an hour may be empirically treated with topical pilocarpine and other intraocular pressure-lowering agents (eg, timolol, apraclonidine). (Choice B) There is no compelling evidence that opiates, such as intravenous morphine, are effective for cluster headache. (Choice D) Topical corticosteroids are usually indicated for noninfectious anterior uveitis (iritis). Anterior uveitis can present with eye pain, conjunctivitis, and a miotic pupil; however, it is often associated with loss of vision and would not explain this patient's ipsilateral lacrimation and rhinorrhea. Educational objective: Cluster headache typically presents with multiple short attacks of severe unilateral periorbital, supraorbital, or temporal pain associated with restlessness and ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (eg, ptosis, miosis, lacrimation, conjunctival injection, rhinorrhea/nasal congestion). Acute therapy usually involves oxygen and/or sumatriptan. Verapamil is the preferred agent for chronic preventive therapy.

stem: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to left arm weakness and slurred speech, which he first noticed on waking this morning. He is accompanied by his wife, who says that his symptoms improved markedly after 2 hours, but then worsened again significantly an hour ago. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. He had a bare metal stent placed in his left circumflex artery 7 years ago. The patient also has chronic kidney disease with an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 50 mL/min/1.73 m. His medications include aspirin, metformin, carvedilol, and lisinopril. The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history. His mother had polycystic kidney disease and his father died of a heart attack. Blood pressure is 175/105 mm Hg and pulse is 65/min and regular. On neurologic examination, the patient is awake and alert. He has a left-homonymous hemianopsia, right forced gaze deviation, reduced sensation on the left side of the face, and left lower facial paresis. He also has left-sided hemiplegia with an extensor plantar response. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's current condition?
explanation: This patient's focal neurologic deficits are consistent with a right middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke. MCA strokes typically present with contralateral somatosensory and motor weakness (eg, face, arm, leg). Patients can also have conjugate eye deviation toward the side of infarct, contralateral homonymous hemianopsia (superior and inferior optic radiations), hemineglect (if affecting nondominant hemisphere), or aphasia (if affecting the dominant hemisphere). Causes of ischemic stroke can often be differentiated by the patient's clinical characteristics and progression of symptoms. Thrombotic strokes are due to local (in situ) obstruction of large arteries, usually in areas of underlying atherosclerosis. Patients typically have atherosclerotic risk factors (eg, diabetes, uncontrolled hypertension, previous transient ischemic attack) and develop fluctuating symptoms with periodic improvement and stuttering progression as thrombus is forming in the diseased segment. Embolic strokes are often due to mural thrombus arising remotely in the heart, aorta, or large vessels (eg, atrial fibrillation, paradoxical embolism across patent foramen ovale). Embolic strokes usually involve abrupt onset of focal neurologic findings with maximal symptoms at onset. Patients may have embolic obstruction of multiple vascular territories (Choice B). This patient's fluctuating, progressive neurologic deficits indicate thrombotic ischemic stroke of the MCA. (Choice C) Small-vessel lipohyalinosis typically causes lacunar infarcts due to occlusion of a single penetrating branch of a larger artery. Patients usually develop limited focal motor and/or sensory symptoms, ataxia, or dysarthria. This patient's extensive neurologic deficits, including visual defects and hemiparesis, make lipohyalinosis less likely. (Choice D) Spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage is usually due to a ruptured arterial saccular (berry) aneurysm and presents with sudden-onset headache associated with possible meningismus or focal neurologic deficits. This patient's intermittent symptoms without headache or rapid progression of symptoms make hemorrhagic stroke less likely. (Choice E) Acute subdural hematomas (SDHs) form after rupture of a bridging vein, typically due to trauma. They present with a "lucid interval" before progression to coma, typically within 24-48 hours after onset. Chronic SDHs may present with slowly progressive cognitive impairment, headaches, and seizures weeks after onset. Educational objective: Ischemic stroke is classified as embolic or thrombotic. Embolic strokes usually have abrupt onset of focal neurologic findings with maximal symptoms at onset. Thrombotic strokes usually present as fluctuating symptoms with periodic improvement and stuttering progression.

stem: A 60-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for acute onset of low back pain radiating down her left leg after lifting heavy boxes at home. She denies any muscle weakness and has no problems with bowel or bladder function. She states that her back pain worsens with coughing or bearing down. Her past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She recently received a flu shot which made her experience mild flu-like symptoms. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for many years, but denies alcohol use. Her temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, and pulse is 90/min and regular. Neurological examination reveals 5/5 muscle strength in all four extremities with 2+ reflexes. Straight leg raise sign is positive on the left. Sensory examination reveals reduced pinprick and temperature sensation along the posterolateral region of the left leg. Basic metabolic panel is normal. Plain radiograph of the lumbar spine shows only degenerative changes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
choice_c: Light exercise with a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug
choice_d: MRI of the lumbar spine with and without contrast
explanation: This patient's symptoms - back pain radiating down the leg which is worsened with coughing or bearing down - are consistent with an acute lumbosacral radiculopathy (ALSR). ALSR is most often due to a mechanical compression of the L5 and/or S1 dorsal root, usually by a herniated disk. ALSR typically presents with low back and leg pain (sciatica), often with associated numbness and/or weakness in the leg. Reproduction of radicular pain with flexion at the hip and dorsiflexion at the ankle (positive straight leg raise) is relatively specific for the diagnosis. Most patients with ALSR will have spontaneous improvement, and can be managed with conservative measures for comfort. Studies of various medications in ALSR have largely been mixed, though non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are often effective and are well tolerated. Anti-spasmodics/muscle relaxants may also be considered, but they are associated with significant sedation and inconsistent benefits. Opioids appear to be less effective and are associated with sedation and a significant risk of dependence. Pain-modifying drugs such as gabapentin are primarily used for chronic symptoms and also cause significant sedation (Choice B). Patients with ALSR should usually be advised to maintain light-normal activity. A brief period of bed rest (<3 days) is also acceptable, but extended bed rest has been shown to provide no benefit and may prolong recovery. If the patient's symptoms fail to improve, or there are new neurological deficits at follow-up, magnetic resonance imaging of the lumbo-sacral spine and surgical referral may be indicated. (Choice A) Bone density testing should be considered if there is evidence of compression fracture or sacral insufficiency fracture. This patient's x-rays show no evidence of fracture. (Choice D) Early magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) should be considered for patients with low back pain or ALSR who have clinical features to suggest a malignant or infectious etiology (eg, fever, history of malignancy, intravenous drug abuse) or significant neurologic deficit (eg, saddle anesthesia, urinary retention, gross motor weakness). But MRI has been shown to not improve care in patients with uncomplicated back pain or ALSR. (Choice E) Physical therapy and spinal manipulation have shown inconsistent results in treatment of ALSR. They may be considered for patients who do not improve with initial therapy but do not wish to pursue invasive interventions. Educational objective: Acute lumbo-sacral radiculopathy is characterized by low back pain associated with radiating pain and/or numbness along a dermatomal distribution (most commonly L5 and S1). Activity modification and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for pain are effective in up to 90% of patients. Magnetic resonance imaging is reserved for patients with acute neurological deficits (i.e., weakness, problems walking, or bowel/bladder difficulties), suspicion for infection or malignancy, or failure to improve with initial management.

stem: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to acute onset of headache, double vision, slurred speech, and left-sided weakness. The patient describes his headache as a throbbing pain at the back of the head. He has had no nausea, vomiting, hiccups, numbness, or difficulty swallowing. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Medications include aspirin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. He is a retired truck driver and smokes a pack of cigarettes a day. Blood pressure is 170/90 mm Hg and pulse is 90/min with regular rhythm. Funduscopic examination is normal with no papilledema. There is no nystagmus; however, there is complete ptosis of the right eye that is depressed and deviated to the right. The right pupil is dilated and nonreactive to light. Confrontational visual fields are normal. There is left lower facial droop. The cough and gag reflexes are intact. The tongue is midline with no fasciculations. There is left-sided hemiplegia with an extensor plantar response. There is also increased cogwheel rigidity in the left upper extremity. A non contrast CT scan of the head is negative for acute hemorrhage. A lesion in which of the following areas is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
choice_a: Brainstem at the level of the medulla oblongata
choice_b: Brainstem at the level of the midbrain
choice_d: Cerebral cortex in the distribution of the middle cerebral artery
choice_e: Posterior limb of the internal capsule
explanation: This patient with multiple vascular risk factors (eg, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, smoking) has an acute, right-sided, non-pupil-sparing, cranial nerve (CN) III palsy, along with left lower facial weakness and left-sided hemiplegia consistent with an acute ischemic stroke, likely in the brainstem. The brainstem is where most cranial nerves originate and where many motor and sensory fibers cross the midline; therefore, brainstem stroke should be considered in patients who have acute CN deficits accompanied by contralateral hemiparesis or hemisensory loss (crossed signs). CN involvement can help with localization based on the origin within the brainstem: Midbrain (CNs III-IV): oculomotor (III), trochlear (IV); Pons (CNs V-VIII): trigeminal (V), abducens (VI), facial (VII), vestibulocochlear (VIII); Medulla oblongata (CNs IX-XII): glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), spinal accessory (XI), hypoglossal (XII). The olfactory (CN I) and optic (CN II) nerves originate in the cerebrum and are not affected in brainstem stroke. This patient with right CN III palsy and crossed signs (eg, left hemiparesis) has an ischemic stroke at the level of the midbrain, sometimes known as Weber syndrome. (Choice A) Strokes at the level of the medullar oblongata cause similar brainstem symptoms (eg, crossed findings, CN involvement); however, CN III involvement is unexpected. Stroke involving the medial medulla can cause tongue weakness (CN XII), whereas lateral medullary strokes can present with ipsilateral Horner syndrome (eg, ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis). Because the respiratory center is located in the medulla, large strokes may cause respiratory compromise. (Choice C) Strokes of the cerebellar hemisphere typically result in ipsilateral ataxia and nystagmus without weakness or numbness. Cranial nerve deficits are not typically seen in cerebellar stroke. (Choice D) An acute cortical stroke in the distribution of the middle cerebral artery would cause contralateral hemiplegia and sensory loss. Aphasia may occur if the dominant hemisphere is involved, but cranial nerve dysfunction is rare. (Choice E) An acute stroke in the posterior limb of the internal capsule would cause a lacunar stroke syndrome. Patients can have contralateral hemiparesis, sensory loss, and occasionally facial weakness. However, strokes in the posterior internal capsule do not usually cause cogwheel rigidity or cranial nerve deficits. Educational objective: Brainstem (ie, midbrain, pons, medulla oblongata) strokes should be considered in patients with acute cranial nerve (CN) deficits and crossed signs (contralateral hemiparesis or hemisensory loss). CN III dysfunction with contralateral hemiplegia suggests a stroke at the level of the midbrain.

stem: A 32-year-old right-handed woman with no significant past medical history is brought to the emergency department with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. Before the seizure, her husband noticed the patient fumbling with the buttons on her shirt and smacking her lips. Following the seizure, she appeared to be confused for 30-40 minutes. The patient states that she could not sleep the night before due to a deadline at work. She has no history of head trauma, fevers, headaches, or vision problems. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is awake, cooperative, and follows commands. Her speech is fluent and her repetition is appropriate. The remainder of her mental status and neurologic examinations shows no abnormalities. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain reveals an infiltrating 2-cm lesion in the temporal lobe that produces no mass effect and is most consistent with a low-grade glioma. Neurosurgery evaluation is pending. What is the best next step in management of this patient?
choice_e: Reassurance and no medical intervention at this time
explanation: This patient presents with a single provoked complex partial seizure that secondarily generalized in a structural lesion in the brain. A complex partial seizure is a focal seizure that arises from a cerebral hemisphere and causes alteration/loss of consciousness or awareness. During a complex partial seizure, some patients may display semi-purposeful behaviors called automatisms (eg, lip smacking, pacing, grooming behavior, repetitive swallowing). Patients are completely unaware of these behaviors and have no memory of them after the seizure. Complex partial seizures can arise from any region of the cortex but are seen most frequently in patients with mesial temporal lobe epilepsy. In general, neurologists do not treat with an antiepileptic drug (AED) unless the patient has had >=2 unprovoked seizures separated by more than 24 hours. In this patient, the seizure was provoked by an underlying structural lesion in the brain. Therefore, treatment with an AED is indicated as the risk of seizure recurrence is high. Given that this patient is of reproductive age, lamotrigine alone or levetiracetam is the best AED to start as it has the fewest teratogenic side effects. Valproic acid is generally contraindicated in young women of reproductive age due to potential teratogenic effects. (Choice A) An electroencephalogram (EEG) for risk stratification is not necessary in this patient as she is already at high risk for seizure recurrence given the presence of a structural lesion on brain imaging. An EEG is helpful for risk stratification in patients with normal brain imaging. (Choice D) Lorazepam is the initial drug of choice for status epilepticus, defined as a prolonged single seizure of > 5-10 minutes or repetitive seizures without return to baseline clinical status between episodes. This patient's presentation is not consistent with status epilepticus. Educational objective: A single focal seizure due to a structural brain lesion has a high risk of recurrence and requires treatment with an antiepileptic drug.

stem: A 76-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to intermittent blurry vision for the past 3 days. Today he feels as though "a curtain is falling in front" of his right eye. Family members have been worried about a decline in his general health over the past month as he has been eating less and has been less socially active. The patient has "felt down" for several weeks and has had headaches, a decreased appetite, and difficulty eating solid foods due to pain while chewing. Medical history is notable for hypertension, intermittent atrial fibrillation, mild dementia, and a transient ischemic episode 6 months ago. A carotid ultrasonogram performed 6 months ago showed 40% stenosis in the carotid arteries bilaterally. Current medications include triamterene, hydrochlorothiazide, dabigatran, atorvastatin, and aspirin. The patient retired from coal mining 20 years ago and lives alone in an apartment. He does not use tobacco but drinks alcohol on social occasions. Blood pressure is 142/78 mm Hg, and pulse is 78/min and regular. On physical examination, the pupils are reactive to light. Visual acuity is 20/40 in the left eye and 20/100 in the right eye. There is no scalp tenderness. The oropharyngeal mucosa is dry and no lymph nodes are palpable. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. The abdomen is soft and there is no organomegaly. Upper and lower limb deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Muscle power is 5/5 in all extremities. Laboratory results are as follows: Hemoglobin 10.1 g/dL, Mean corpuscular volume 89 um, Platelets 350,000/mm, Sodium 134 mEq/L, Potassium 4.2 mEq/L, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL, Creatine kinase, serum 180 U/L, Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 52 mm/h. Chest x-ray reveals no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's condition?
choice_b: Brain MRI and carotid MR angiography
explanation: This patient's presentation is highly concerning for giant cell arteritis (GCA) given his systemic symptoms (fatigue, loss of appetite), headaches, jaw claudication, amaurosis fugax (acute unilateral vision loss), normocytic anemia, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). Ophthalmology consultation and a temporal artery biopsy, which confirms the diagnosis, are required; however, high-dose systemic glucocorticoids (eg, prednisone) should be given immediately to prevent complications (eg, optic neuropathy causing blindness) while awaiting biopsy results. Low-dose aspirin is also recommended to reduce risk of cranial ischemic complications (eg, stroke). Early symptoms of GCA are often nonspecific, and elderly patients may not come for evaluation until visual symptoms develop. Jaw claudication (eg, pain with chewing), seen in up to 50% of cases, has high specificity for GCA; temporal artery swelling and tenderness are helpful findings, but many patients have no scalp tenderness. Although ESR elevation increases the likelihood of diagnosis, GCA and polymyalgia rheumatica (shoulder/neck/hip girdle aching and morning stiffness) can occur with a normal ESR (up to 20% of cases in some series). Conversely, although these conditions do not cause a rise in muscle enzyme (eg, creatine kinase) levels, elderly patients frequently have comorbid diagnoses or medications (eg, statins) causing elevations in these enzymes; therefore, a mildly elevated creatine kinase cannot be used to rule out GCA. (Choice A) If patients develop a thrombotic stroke while on aspirin, dipyridamole can be added. (Choices B and C) This patient has known carotid atherosclerosis and a recent transient ischemic attack. MR angiography is helpful in diagnosing carotid dissection and carotid stenosis, and carotid endarterectomy would be considered in a symptomatic man with >=50% stenosis. Although carotid atherosclerosis can cause amaurosis fugax, this patient's constitutional symptoms, elevated ESR, and jaw claudication are more consistent with GCA; empiric glucocorticoid therapy is the most appropriate next step. (Choice E) Heparin would be beneficial for ophthalmic circulation in embolic stroke; however, this patient is already anticoagulated on dabigatran, and the systemic symptoms and jaw pain make GCA more likely than stroke. Educational objective: Clinical features of giant cell arteritis include systemic symptoms, headaches, jaw claudication, and amaurosis fugax. Inflammatory markers (eg, erythrocyte sedimentation rate) are usually elevated. Temporal artery biopsy is the preferred confirmatory test, but patients should be started on immediate high-dose glucocorticoids to prevent vision loss while awaiting biopsy results.

stem: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking that began one hour ago. His other medical problems include hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has no history of stroke, myocardial infarction, recent trauma or surgery, or bleeding. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. His medications include hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, amlodipine, and simvastatin. His temperature is 37.0 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg, and pulse is 115/min. On neurological examination, he is awake and alert. He has significant expressive aphasia and difficulty with repetition. He has right-sided hemiparesis (arm>leg) and numbness. His reflexes are increased on the right with an extensor plantar response. His EKG shows an irregularly irregular rhythm and nonspecific T wave changes. Laboratory results show Hemoglobin 14.5 g/dL, Platelets 300,000 cells/uL, Glucose 70 mg/dL, Activated partial thromboplastin time 18 sec, and International Normalized Ratio (INR) 1.1. A head CT is negative for hemorrhage. After initial evaluation, he is treated with intravenous tPA. Which of the following is the most important step in the management of this patient within the next 24 hours?
choice_e: Labetalol to keep systolic blood pressure < 180 mm Hg
explanation: This patient is likely presenting with an acute ischemic embolic stroke to the left superior division of the middle cerebral artery secondary to atrial fibrillation. This patient has received IV tPA therapy, and therefore his blood pressure in the first 24 hours must be maintained < 180/105 mm Hg to reduce the risk of intracerebral hemorrhage. (Choice A) Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic that is used for chemical cardioversion of atrial fibrillation. In this case, cardioversion will increase the risk of further cardioembolic events from re-establishment of the atrial kick. (Choice B) Aspirin should be avoided in the first 24 hours after IV tPA administration. Following the initial 24-hour period, aspirin may be started if the repeat non-contrast head CT shows no bleeding and the patient is not a candidate for anticoagulation for the atrial fibrillation. (Choice C) Early enteral feeding is not recommended in patients receiving tPA. These patients need to be kept NPO for at least 24 hours in the event of hemorrhagic conversion requiring possible surgery to lower intracranial pressure. (Choice D) Intravenous heparin infusion may be started only after the first 24 hours following IV tPA if a non-contrast head CT shows no hemorrhagic transformation or a diffusion-weighted MRI of the brain shows no evidence of a large completed infarct (> 33% of cerebral hemisphere). Educational objective: Within the first 24 hours of intravenous tPA treatment, the patient's blood pressure should be maintained < 180/105 mm Hg. Early enteral feeding, anticoagulants, and anti-platelet agents should be avoided for the first 24 hours until repeat CT head imaging shows no hemorrhagic conversion.

stem: A 65-year-old woman with a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension is brought to the emergency department due to double vision and right eye pain. She awoke 2 days ago with right periorbital pain, and several hours later, she noticed double vision that became worse with accommodation. The double vision has been persistent and does not fluctuate throughout the day. The patient has had no headaches, blurry vision, dysarthria, dysphasia, weakness, numbness, or balance problems. Medications include aspirin, lisinopril, and metformin. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg seated and pulse is 80/min. Neurologic examination shows both horizontal and vertical binocular diplopia with left lateral and upward gazes. There is complete ptosis of the right eyelid, with the eyeball in the down-and-out position. The right pupil is 5 mm, midposition, and nonreactive to light; the left pupil is 3 mm, midposition, and reactive to light. The anisocoria improves with the ambient light off. No eye proptosis, conjunctival injection, periorbital edema, chemosis, or ocular bruit is present. Funduscopic examination reveals no papilledema. The rest of the neurologic examination is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
choice_b: MRI diffusion-weighted sequence of the brain
choice_d: Serum creatine phosphokinase and aldolase testing
explanation: This patient with diabetes mellitus and hypertension who presents with horizontal and vertical binocular diplopia, ptosis, and a nonreactive pupil has an isolated, acute, non-pupil-sparing third nerve palsy. Injury to the third nerve can occur anywhere along its length, from its origin in the brainstem to the orbit. The parasympathetic fibers responsible for pupil constriction (by controlling the sphincter papillae muscle) run on the outside of the third nerve fascicle and are less susceptible to ischemia but are almost invariably affected by an extrinsic mass. Therefore, third nerve palsies are classically classified as follows: Non-pupil-sparing third nerve palsies are frequently caused by mass effect (eg, intracranial aneurysm, tumor). Aneurysms arise from vessels that have a close anatomic relationship with the third nerve (eg, posterior cerebral artery, superior cerebellar artery, posterior communicating artery). A non-pupil-sparing third nerve palsy (as seen in this patient) should be considered due to an aneurysm until proved otherwise; patients should undergo immediate MR or CT angiography for evaluation. Pupil-sparing third nerve palsies are typically caused by microvascular ischemia; they are associated with diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and advanced age. Observation and supportive care may be appropriate in patients with vasculopathic risk factors (eg, diabetes, hypertension), although some physicians advocate for imaging to exclude mass effect with all third nerve palsies (Choice E). It is important to note that aneurysms may spare the pupil early in the course and that, rarely, patients with microvascular disease may develop complete infarction with pupillary involvement. Therefore, imaging should be considered if the presentation is atypical (eg, if patients develop a pupil-sparing third nerve palsy without having vasculopathic risk factors, if symptoms fail to improve within 6-12 weeks). (Choice B) Non-pupil-sparing third nerve palsy can be caused by an acute brainstem or lacunar stroke; however, patients typically have other deficits. In the case of an isolated non-pupil-sparing third nerve palsy, aneurysmal compression of the third nerve must be ruled out first. If vascular imaging does not reveal an aneurysm, then an MRI of the brain with diffusion protocol can be considered to rule out a small infarct. (Choice C) Myasthenia gravis presents with fluctuating diplopia; the presence of acetylcholine receptor antibodies can confirm the diagnosis. However, the pupillary light reflex is spared, and pain is not a typical feature in myasthenia gravis. (Choice D) Myopathy affecting the extraocular muscles can occur in rare conditions (eg, muscular dystrophy) and causes elevated creatine phosphokinase and aldolase levels. Myopathies typically present with bilateral symptoms affecting skeletal muscles; pupillary light reflex is spared. Educational objective: Non-pupil-sparing third nerve palsies are most concerning for aneurysmal compression; MR or CT angiography should be performed immediately. Pupil-sparing third nerve palsies are most commonly caused by microvascular ischemia associated with diabetes mellitus.

stem: A 55-year-old right-handed man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining injuries in a head-on motor vehicle collision. He has a past medical history of migraine headaches, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient is a chronic smoker, and his medications include aspirin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. On the way to CT scan, he complains of a severe, sharp headache that radiates to the left side of his neck. His blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg and pulse is 102/min and regular. After the head CT is obtained, the patient is unable to speak and develops right-sided weakness. On examination, he is globally aphasic. He has a right homonymous hemianopsia, left pupillary miosis and partial ptosis, and left gaze preference. Neurologic examination shows reduced sensation on the right side of the face and body, right-sided hemiparesis, and an extensor response at the right big toe on plantar cutaneous stimulation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient's presentation suggests acute traumatic left internal carotid artery (ICA) dissection causing ipsilateral middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke and ipsilateral Horner syndrome. Vascular dissections commonly cause acute stroke in patients age <55 and are categorized as traumatic or spontaneous (Table). ICA dissection leads to blood entering between the inner and outer arterial layers, which can form blood clots and also lead to embolic stroke. Non-ischemic ICA dissection typically presents with a thunderclap headache (reaching maximal intensity in < 1 minute) that radiates to the neck. Ischemic dissections may present with transient vision loss, ischemic stroke, or embolic stroke. Because post-ganglionic sympathetic fibers run on the outer surface of the ICA to supply the head, ICA dissection may damage these fibers and lead to partial ipsilateral Horner syndrome (partial ptosis and miosis without anhidrosis). Neck imaging (MRA/CTA is preferred) may show the ICA with a tapered, flame-shaped appearance rather than the blunted-stump appearance of vascular occlusions (Figure). Prompt recognition and treatment (eg, anticoagulation, antiplatelet therapy, and endovascular or surgical endovascular repair) can decrease the risk of stroke, neurologic disability, and death. (Choice B) Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis can present with thunderclap or gradual headache associated with focal neurologic deficits. However, it usually does not present with Horner syndrome. (Choice C) Complex migraine is considered a diagnosis of exclusion and can present with throbbing headache associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and focal neurologic deficits. However, the headache is rarely described as a thunderclap and is not associated with Horner syndrome. (Choice D) Subarachnoid hemorrhage can present with a thunderclap headache and meningeal signs but usually does not present with Horner syndrome. (Choice E) Vertebral dissection can present with thunderclap headache, Horner syndrome due to infarction of the ipsilateral dorsolateral medulla (Wallenberg syndrome), loss of sensation on the face and contralateral body, nystagmus, ataxia, and dysarthria. However, aphasia and weakness are not typically seen in this condition. Educational objective: ICA dissection typically occurs after head or neck trauma with acute neurologic deficits, headache that may radiate to the neck, and possible Horner syndrome. MRA/CTA of the neck is preferred to diagnose vascular dissection (ICA or vertebral), which typically has a flame-shaped, tapered appearance. Prompt recognition and treatment can decrease the risk of stroke, neurologic disability, and death.

stem: A 25-year-old man sustained a head injury during a motor vehicle accident. He is currently comatose and intubated in the intensive care unit. He has no significant medical problems except for mild asthma. His urine drug screen was negative; however, his blood alcohol level was above the legal limit. He works as a bartender and frequently binges on hard liquor and beer. A non-contrast head CT at the time of admission revealed a hyperdense, extra-axial, space-occupying, right-sided lesion, which was subsequently drained. He was sedated with a propofol infusion, but it was discontinued 12 hours ago. His temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), pulse is 80/min, blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg, and respirations are 18/min. He is currently on volume assist-control ventilation with an FiO2 of 40%, tidal volume of 500 cc, and PEEP of 5 cm H2O. He is not triggering the ventilator. The general physical examination is unremarkable except for a hemi-craniectomy along the right side of the head. He is comatose on neurological examination. Cranial nerve and motor responses are absent. His arterial blood gas analysis shows a pH of 7.42, PaCO2 of 36 mm Hg, and PaO2 of 101 mm Hg. Which of the following is essential in establishing the diagnosis of brain death in this patient?
explanation: When clinical criteria suggest brain death, the best next step is apnea testing. Patients must be hemodynamically stable with a body temperature >36 C (97 F), normal pH, and normal PaCO2/PaO2 levels. Apnea testing objectively confirms brainstem failure if the patient cannot generate spontaneous breaths or trigger the ventilator in response to elevated PaCO2 levels > 10 minutes after disabling control mode (Choice E). Patients are first pre-oxygenated with 100% oxygen for 10 minutes using existing ventilatory support, and then mechanical ventilation is discontinued. However, they should continue to passively receive 100% oxygen while the chest and abdomen are observed for spontaneous respirations for approximately 10 minutes. If spontaneous respirations are observed, the apnea test is negative and the patient is not brain dead. A positive test is defined as no spontaneous respirations and requires another clinical brain death examination for confirmation. In addition, repeat ABG must confirm that the PaCO2 was >60 mm Hg or that it increased >20 mm Hg from the baseline ABG. Patients who cannot tolerate apnea testing or have inconclusive results require ancillary diagnostic tests to confirm brain death. (Choice A) The atropine response test involves administering atropine and observing for an increase in heart rate (>3%). Although the vagal nucleus in the medulla may be one of the last functions lost in brain death, the atropine response test provides a limited assessment and has not been well validated for confirming brain death. (Choice C) Cerebral blood flow testing (e.g., cerebral angiogram or cerebral scintigraphy) is the gold standard test for brain death confirmation, but it is highly invasive and not used routinely as the initial step for diagnosing brain death. Cerebral blood flow testing may be used in patients with an unreliable clinical examination or bedside apnea test. (Choice D) Current guidelines do not recommend EEG with ECI protocol for brain death confirmation, as it is susceptible to excessive artifact from other electrical devices in the ICU that make it less reliable. In addition, EEG is very sensitive to the effects of sedative medications and metabolic derangements, and therefore can be easily confounded by those variables. Educational objective: Brain death can be suggested by clinical criteria (e.g., coma, absent cranial nerve reflexes and motor responses, CT/MRI brain imaging consistent with a devastating CNS event, etc.). Two clinical brain death examinations and apnea testing are recommended and considered appropriate for brain death diagnosis. Every attempt should be made to remove all confounding variables that can interfere with obtaining a reliable clinical examination and bedside apnea test.

stem: A 56-year-old man with a past medical history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus is hospitalized after sustaining a mild concussion following a motor vehicle accident. His daily medications include aspirin, metformin, and lisinopril. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He does not drink alcohol. He is married and works as an accountant. His family history is significant for coronary artery disease and diabetes mellitus. His blood pressure is 143/95 mm Hg and pulse is 90/min with regular rhythm. His general physical and neurological examinations are unremarkable. An MRI of the brain without contrast reveals a chronic infarct in the right basal ganglia without any evidence of intracranial bleeding. This patient is at the highest risk for which of the following?
explanation: This patient's brain MRI shows a silent, chronic lacunar infarct in the right basal ganglia related to his hypertension and diabetes mellitus. Given his vascular risk factors, he is at risk of having additional ischemic events. These events can accumulate over time and cause significant damage to the surrounding white matter tracts and subcortical grey matter, which are essential for proper cognitive function. One study found that patients with silent infarcts with positive brain imaging have double the risk of developing dementia over the subsequent 5 years, compared to normal controls with normal brain imaging. Multiple silent infarcts were associated with an even higher risk than single infarcts. Therefore, this patient is at risk for developing vascular (Binswanger's) dementia in the future. (Choice B) Migraine headaches are a common primary headache disorder typically afflicting patients between the ages of 15-50 years. Migraine headaches (especially those associated with prolonged negative aura) can lead to migrainous cerebral infarction from headache-induced changes in vascular tone or caliber. However, vascular risk factors and stroke have not been linked to a higher future risk of developing migraine headaches. (Choice C) Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune demyelinating disease that predominantly affects the central white matter of the brain and spinal cord. Vascular risk factors and stroke have not been linked with an increased future risk of developing multiple sclerosis. (Choice D) Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a disorder characterized by ataxia, dementia, and urinary incontinence. This condition develops as a result of impaired cerebrospinal fluid absorption at the arachnoid granulations and has no causal relationship with ischemic events in the brain. (Choice E) The risk of developing seizures following an acute stroke is approximately 5-10% if the stroke involves the cortex. Subcortical strokes typically do not increase the risk of seizures. Severe concussions (e.g., associated with loss of consciousness or amnesia) can lead to a high risk of developing epilepsy later in life. However, this patient only had a mild concussion, and therefore has a low risk for epilepsy. Educational objective: Elderly people with silent brain infarcts have an increased risk of developing dementia than those without such lesions.

stem: A 46-year-old man comes to the emergency department complaining of severe headache for the last 3 hours. He took ibuprofen without much relief. He suffers from tension headaches but says that this headache is nothing like those. He feels nauseated and wants to move to a quiet, dark room. His temperature is 36.5 C (97.7 F), blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg, and pulse is 108/min. Examination shows pain and mild stiffness with neck flexion. There are no cranial nerve deficits or muscle weakness. A noncontrast head computed tomography scan reveals subarachnoid hemorrhage with no evidence of hydrocephalus. The patient is admitted to the intensive care unit. A few hours later, he complains of increasing headache and has 2 episodes of vomiting. Soon after, he develops cardiac arrest with pulseless electrical activity. Which of the following interventions would have been the most effective in preventing this outcome?
explanation: This patient has a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) in the setting of severe headache and meningismus. SAH has a mortality rate of nearly 10% before patients reach the hospital and 25% within the first 24 hours of presentation. Rebleeding is the major cause of death within the first 24 hours, particularly within the first 6 hours. The initial step in managing suspected SAH is conventional angiogram as soon as possible with an endovascular approach (eg, coiling and/or stenting) to stabilize the aneurysm. (Choice A) Anti-fibrinolytic therapy (eg, tranexamic acid, epsilon aminocaproic acid) has not been shown to be effective in preventing rebleeding in patients with SAH. (Choices C and D) Hyperdynamic therapy (modest hemodilution, induced hypertension, hypervolemia) and nimodipine can effectively reduce the risk of vasospasm. However, this usually does not occur until after day 3. This patient's clinical course within the first 24 hours of SAH is most likely due to rebleeding. (Choice E) Ventricular drain placement is helpful in reducing intracranial pressure and increasing cerebral perfusion pressure. However, this patient's catastrophic event is likely due to rebleeding. Educational objective: In patients with subarachnoid hemorrhage, rebleeding is the major cause of death within the first 24 hours of presentation. Vasospasm usually does not occur until day 3.

stem: A 46-year-old woman is seen in the emergency department for severe headache accompanied by nausea since she awoke this morning. She was diagnosed with hypertension 7 years ago and took medications for 2 years. The patient stopped the medications and did not follow up with doctors as she felt fine. She has a history of remote but not active intravenous drug use. She is a current smoker with a 25-pack-year history. Her temperature is 37.8 C (100.1 F), blood pressure is 176/105 mm Hg, and pulse is 100/min. She appears lethargic with mild neck stiffness. Cardiac auscultation shows an apical 2/6 holosystolic murmur. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Deep abdominal palpation shows bilateral firm flank masses. There is no peripheral edema or skin rash. There is no focal muscle weakness or cranial nerve deficit. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with left ventricular hypertrophy and secondary ST-segment and T-wave changes. Laboratory results show Creatinine 2.2 mg/dL, Glucose 80 mg/dL, and Urinalysis with Protein +1 and Red blood cells 10-20/hpf. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's headache?
explanation: This patient's presentation of hypertension, hematuria, proteinuria, renal insufficiency, and bilateral flank masses suggests likely autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Major extrarenal complications of ADPKD are: Intracranial aneurysms, Hepatic and pancreatic cysts, Cardiac valve disease and aortic root dilatation, Diverticulosis. Nearly 5% of young adults and 20% of patients > age 60 with ADPKD develop intracranial aneurysms that can rupture causing intracerebral or subarachnoid hemorrhage. This risk is higher in patients with family history of ruptured aneurysms. Patients typically present with "thunderclap" headache, nausea, and vomiting. Computed tomography (CT) scan usually diagnoses subarachnoid hemorrhage but can sometimes miss small bleeds. Lumbar puncture is indicated in patients with negative CT scan and usually shows xanthochromia. Angiography is recommended for patients with positive CT scan or lumbar puncture. (Choice A) Uncontrolled hypertension, sudden-onset headache, and neck stiffness suggest possible subarachnoid hemorrhage. Bilateral flank masses in this situation indicate underlying ADPKD rather than renal cell carcinoma with metastasis. (Choice B) Although this patient may be at risk for hypertensive encephalopathy, her low-grade fever and neck stiffness indicate subarachnoid hemorrhage. Low-grade fever in general is common with intracranial hemorrhage. Her blood pressure is also not severe enough to cause hypertensive encephalopathy (>180/120 mm Hg). (Choice C) Obstructive or non-communicating hydrocephalus is usually caused by space-occupying lesions. (Choice E) Although this patient's fever and neck stiffness can be due to viral meningitis/encephalitis, the bilateral flank masses, hematuria, and renal insufficiency make ADPKD more likely. Educational objective: Intracranial aneurysms occur in up to 20% of individuals with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.

stem: A 53-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to severe headaches, vomiting, and muscle weakness. The patient's medical problems include hypertension and obesity. Her body mass index is 34.2 kg/m. Temperature is 38 C (100.4 F), blood pressure is 185/105 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 24/min. Pulse oximetry is 99% on room air. The patient is oriented to person and place only, and has a throbbing headache and paralysis of her left side. CT head scan without contrast reveals a right hemisphere hemorrhagic stroke. What is the best next step in preventing deep-vein thrombosis in this patient?
explanation: Deep-vein thrombosis (DVT) is a significant problem in patients with acute stroke, occurring in up to 15% of patients within the first 30 days, with pulmonary embolism (PE) accounting for up to 25% of all early deaths following stroke. DVTs can develop as soon as 24 hours after the acute event, with peak incidence at days 2-7. Risk factors in stroke patients include hemiparesis (with the risk proportionate to the degree of hemiparesis), atrial fibrillation, immobility, and advanced age. Pharmacologic DVT prophylaxis is recommended for ischemic stroke but is contraindicated for hemorrhagic stroke in the acute setting. Intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC) initiated within 72 hours of an acute stroke prevented DVT in the open-label CLOTS 3 trial. Patients who have been immobilized for more than 72 hours should not be started on IPC without first ruling out DVT due to possible clot dislodgement associated with IPC. (Choices A and E) Graduated compression stockings have not been shown to reduce the risk of proximal lower-extremity DVT after stroke. DVT was more common in stroke patients wearing below-knee-high compared with thigh-high graduated compression stockings in the CLOTS 2 trial. In contrast, thigh-high graduated compression stockings may be harmful (eg, skin breaks, blisters, skin necrosis) in stroke patients, according to the CLOTS 1 trial. (Choice B) D-dimer surveillance is not recommended as primary screening prophylaxis for DVT in patients with acute stroke. (Choice D) Pharmacologic DVT prophylaxis with low-molecular-weight heparin may be considered 1-4 days following hemorrhagic stroke in immobile patients as long as repeat imaging rules out further bleeding. Educational objective: In patients with hemorrhagic stroke, intermittent pneumatic compression started within 72 hours of the acute event is effective in preventing deep-vein thrombosis (DVT).

stem: A 72-year-old woman is sent to the hospital after 2 days of agitation and combative behavior. The patient has Alzheimer dementia and lives in a skilled nursing facility. The nursing staff at the facility report that she is calm at baseline and spends most of her time in bed or in a wheelchair. She is normally minimally interactive with staff members but reportedly brightens when her son comes to visit. The patient has a history of generalized anxiety disorder but is currently not taking any medications for it. In the emergency department, the patient is anxious and agitated. She is disoriented to place and time and frequently tries to get out of bed. She intermittently mumbles to herself and accuses the nurse of stealing her handbag. Urinalysis is both leukocyte esterase and nitrite positive and contains 100 white blood cells/high-power field. A urine culture has been sent to the laboratory. In addition to empiric antibiotics for urinary tract infection, which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
choice_d: Have a family member or sitter at bedside
choice_e: Keep the patient in a dark, quiet room
explanation: This patient's acute presentation of worsening confusion and agitated behavior in the setting of a urinary tract infection is consistent with delirium. Initial management of delirium involves the treatment of reversible causes, followed by nonpharmacologic measures such as frequent verbal orientation, reassurance, and touch by someone familiar to the patient (eg, family member) or by a trained sitter at the bedside. Pharmacotherapy is reserved for situations in which nonpharmacologic strategies fail or the patient poses a significant risk of harm to self or others. Preferred agents include first- and second-generation antipsychotics (eg, haloperidol, olanzapine, quetiapine, risperidone) (Choice A). Short-term use is advised as these agents are associated with increased mortality in patients with dementia. Physical restraints are a last resort as they can lead to worsening agitation and result in impaired mobility and pressure ulcers (Choice C). (Choice B) Benzodiazepines (eg, lorazepam) can worsen confusion and cause paradoxical agitation. They are reserved for patients in alcohol withdrawal or those who have contraindications to antipsychotics. (Choice E) During the day, the patient's room should be well lit as darkness can contribute to worsening confusion. Educational objective: Initial management of delirium is aimed at treatment of reversible causes, patient orientation, and environmental modification.

stem: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with progressively worsening dyspnea and generalized weakness. She has had a month of double vision and difficulty swallowing that are significantly worse toward the end of the day. Over the past 2 weeks, she has had difficulty raising her arms above her head and walking up and down stairs. The patient has no headache, speech difficulty, muscle aches, numbness, or paresthesias. She also has no rash, insect bites, recent travel, or illness. On physical examination, the patient has fatigable horizontal binocular diplopia in the primary position and bilateral ptosis. Strength is 4 on a scale of 5 in the proximal muscles of the upper and lower extremities. Sensory examination and reflex testing are unremarkable. Complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and chest x-ray are normal. Vital capacity obtained at the bedside is 500 mL. The patient's respiratory status decompensates, requiring endotracheal intubation and admission to the intensive care unit. Which of the following therapies is the most appropriate for rapidly improving this patient's current condition?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with myasthenic crisis, defined as severe weakness from myasthenia gravis (MG) requiring intubation. Patients in myasthenic crisis can have generalized weakness, respiratory symptoms, or severe oropharyngeal weakness that results in dysphagia and aspiration. Common precipitants include infection and surgery. Patients should be monitored in the intensive care unit, with respiratory status checks every 2-4 hours using vital capacity and maximal inspiratory force. Plasma exchange or intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) are mainstays in initial therapy due to their relatively rapid onset of action, although benefits are transient: These therapies exert their effects within days and have a maximal effect at 3 weeks. Glucocorticoids are added to provide longer-term symptom relief as their onset of action occurs later, at 2-3 weeks, with a peak effect at 5.5 months. However, treatment with high-dose glucocorticoids alone is associated with a transient worsening of MG symptoms and should be initiated only with plasma exchange or IVIG (Choice A). Patients who cannot tolerate glucocorticoids can be started on azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, or cyclosporine, although these drugs have a delayed time of onset compared with glucocorticoids. (Choice B) Trials for using methotrexate as a corticosteroid-sparing agent in generalized MG are ongoing. However, it is not indicated for myasthenic crisis. (Choice D) Anticholinesterase inhibitors (eg, pyridostigmine) should be stopped while the patient is on mechanical ventilation to minimize secretions and aspiration risk. They can be restarted after extubation. (Choice E) Rituximab is useful for refractory MG, especially in patients who have MG with muscle-specific tyrosine-kinase (MuSK) antibodies. However, it is not used in the management of myasthenic crisis. Educational objective: Treatment for patients with myasthenic crisis includes plasma exchange or intravenous immunoglobulin due to their rapid onset of action and peak effect.

stem: An 81-year-old man comes to the physician with an episode of right arm weakness and difficulty finding words. The episode occurred the night before and lasted 90 minutes, followed by slow resolution of symptoms. He had no loss of consciousness. He has never had similar symptoms and otherwise feels fine. The patient's medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His medications include lisinopril, metformin, and glipizide. His last hemoglobin A1c was 7.6%. He quit smoking 5 years ago. The patient's blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg and pulse is 88/min. His body mass index is 30 kg/m. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs. No carotid bruits are heard and lungs are clear to auscultation. Peripheral pulses are full and symmetric. Neurologic examination, including visual field testing, is within normal limits. Fingerstick glucose level is 176 mg/dL. Electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
choice_c: Start insulin for tighter diabetes control
choice_d: Start low-dose aspirin and schedule outpatient carotid duplex imaging
choice_e: Start low-dose aspirin and schedule outpatient MRI of the head
explanation: This patient's presentation suggests transient ischemic attack (TIA), defined as a transient episode of neurologic impairment (of central nervous system origin) without acute infarction. Patients with TIA or minor stroke without residual deficits require immediate evaluation due to higher risk of recurrent stroke. The ABCD score is a prognostic tool designed to predict the risk of ischemic stroke in the first 2 days after TIA. The National Stroke Association recommends hospitalization for all patients with a first TIA within the last 24-48 hours and the following conditions: Duration of symptoms > 1 hour, Symptomatic internal carotid artery stenosis >50%, Multiple recurrent TIAs, Atrial fibrillation or other known cardiac source of embolus, Hypercoagulable state, High risk of stroke after TIA as determined by the ABCD score. This patient's ABCD score is 6, demonstrating a high 2-day stroke risk of 8%. He should be hospitalized for appropriate expedited testing and stroke prevention treatment. (Choice B) Initial TIA workup should include carotid imaging, brain imaging, and electrocardiogram. Patients with negative initial studies should undergo echocardiogram. (Choice C) The ADA recommends hemoglobin A1c < 8.0% for older patients; this patient is at goal. (Choices D and E) This patient's risk factors require immediate hospitalization instead of outpatient evaluation. Educational objective: Patients with recent (within 24-48 hours) TIA and high-risk factors (eg, ABCD score) should be hospitalized for further investigation and prevention.

stem: A 30-year-old woman with a history of episodic migraine headaches comes to the office due to worsening of her headaches. She started having infrequent migraine headaches in her early twenties. However, her migraine headaches have become more severe over the past 1 year and have started to occur >15 days/month. She has been taking ibuprofen on a daily basis for months to treat the headaches, which have only worsened and now occur on a daily basis. Recent MRI of her brain showed no abnormalities. She has not had any fevers, neck stiffness, vision changes, head trauma, double vision, dysarthria, dysphasia, weakness, numbness, or difficulty with balance. Her headaches are not affected by changes in head position, cough, or Valsalva maneuvers; but are made worse by physical activity and are associated with photophobia, and nausea. She works as a secretary and has needed to take leave from work due to her severe headaches. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Her seated blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg and pulse is 76/min. Her BMI is 32 kg/m. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities except for marked photophobia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
choice_a: Discontinue ibuprofen, start a short oral steroid taper, and prescribe topiramate
choice_b: Order a lumbar puncture for opening pressure
choice_c: Order MR venography of the head
explanation: This patient presents with medication-overuse headache (MOH) in the setting of transformed migraine (ie, chronic migraine). Chronic migraine is defined as a unilateral headache that occurs >15 days/month for >3 consecutive months. MOH can occur when a patient takes daily analgesics for >15 days/month. Treatment requires immediate discontinuation of the offending analgesic agent. Patients typically have significant worsening of their headaches after discontinuation; therefore, they require a bridging agent (usually a short 1-2-week course of oral steroids). In addition, this patient needs a migraine preventive (eg, topiramate), which is a good choice given her obesity and its weight-loss side effect. (Choice B) A lumbar puncture is indicated for suspected idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). Clinical features of IIH include worsening of headache with lying flat and visual changes, which are absent here. (Choice C) MRV is used to exclude cerebral sinus venous thrombosis in patients with clinical findings of increased ICP. (Choice D) Acetazolamide is for IIH. (Choice E) Topiramate alone does not address the MOH. Educational objective: Medication-overuse headache needs to be addressed by discontinuation of the offending agent and introduction of a short steroid taper.

stem: A 64-year-old man comes to the physician because of a tremor. He first began experiencing a tremor in his right hand two years ago that gradually has involved his left hand. The tremor worsens when he drinks from a glass of water or tries to tie his shoes. His other medical problems include hypertension treated with lisinopril. He does not smoke cigarettes, but drinks occasionally and mentions that his tremor improves with a glass of wine. His father died of old age and had a "movement problem" in his later years. His blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, pulse is 84/min, and respirations are 12/min. At rest, he appears comfortable sitting on the examination table. He has 5/5 muscle strength in all extremities and has no obvious resting tremor. When asked to touch his finger to his nose, a tremor is present that increases when his finger touches his nose. His head also appears to have a mild tremor as he stands up that decreases once he sits down. His gait appears to be normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with an essential tremor (ET), which is the most common cause of postural or action tremors. Resting tremors change with movement, whereas action tremors (ET) remain unchanged or worsen with movement. Patients typically present with an action tremor without other focal neurological signs. ET can involve the head without dystonia. Alcohol consumption often improves symptoms. Treatment usually involves propranolol or primidone. (Choice A) Cerebellar stroke causing a tremor is usually associated with ataxia and dysmetria. A cerebellar tremor tends to increase steadily as the hand approaches the target. (Choice C) Hyperthyroidism usually causes acute onset of high frequency, low amplitude tremors and would be accompanied by other signs like tachycardia. (Choice D) Multiple sclerosis can present with spasticity but not usually this type of tremor. (Choice E) Parkinson's tremor is a resting tremor (4-6 Hz) that decreases with voluntary movement and is associated with bradykinesia and rigidity. Educational objective: Essential tremor is the most common action tremor, often involving the hands and worsening at the end of goal-directed movements.

stem: A 73-year-old woman comes to the physician for routine follow-up and medication refill. She has experienced an acute onset of hand shaking over the last couple of weeks. It has significantly affected her daily activities, especially pouring tea and knitting. She has no chest pain, anxiety, shortness of breath, lower-extremity edema, or weight loss. She has had no recent falls. The patient has taken atenolol and hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension for many years but ran out of medications about a month ago and has not renewed them until today. Her blood pressure is 152/76 mm Hg and pulse is 85/min. Her thyroid gland is not enlarged. A mild tremor of outstretched hands is seen bilaterally. Romberg maneuver is negative for any signs. Gait is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with essential or benign tremor. Essential tremor (ET) is autosomal dominant and usually presents in the 5th or 6th decade of life. ET is induced by action or posture (postural tremor) and increases during goal-directed movements. This patient likely had ET that was being masked or treated by her atenolol; when she ran out of medication, the tremor became clinically apparent. (Choice A) Beta blocker withdrawal can present with tremors, but these usually occur acutely within 24-36 hours. This patient's symptoms have lasted weeks. (Choice B) Cerebellar strokes cause intention tremors with other cerebellar signs (eg, ataxic gait). (Choice D) Hyperthyroidism can cause fine postural tremors, but other symptoms (weight loss, anxiety) are missing. (Choice E) Parkinson's involves resting tremors and bradykinesia. Educational objective: Essential tremor is an autosomal dominant tremor induced by action or posture, commonly affecting the upper extremities. Treatment involves beta blockers (eg, propranolol) or primidone.

stem: A 58-year-old man comes to the office due to tremor in his right hand. The patient first noticed the tremor a year ago, and it has progressively worsened to the point that he has difficulty writing. He often becomes self-conscious and feels embarrassed in social situations. The patient has had no headache, vision impairment, difficulty speaking or swallowing, sleep disturbances, bowel or bladder incontinence, extremity weakness or numbness, or memory loss. He has a history of hypertension for which he takes lisinopril. The patient is an attorney and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Family history is unremarkable. Neurologic examination shows a Mini-Mental State Examination score of 29/30. A low-frequency tremor is noted in the right hand when resting the arm on a chair. The tremor is exacerbated by mental distraction such as counting backward and becomes less prominent with voluntary activity such as reaching for a pen. When the patient writes, his words become progressively smaller and illegible. There is mild rigidity of the bilateral upper extremities with decreased arm swing during ambulation. The remainder of the neurologic examination shows no other abnormalities. Blood cell counts, serum chemistry studies, and thyroid function tests are within normal limits. MRI of the brain shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This patient has tremor-predominant idiopathic Parkinson disease (PD), characterized by bradykinesia, cogwheel rigidity, and resting tremor. In mild to moderate disease and patients age <65, dopamine agonists (eg, bromocriptine, pramipexole, ropinirole) are generally preferred as they are associated with fewer motor fluctuations compared to levodopa. (Choice A) Deep-brain stimulation is for medically refractory cases. (Choice B) Donepezil is for dementia, which this patient does not have (MMSE 29/30). (Choice D) Propranolol is for essential tremor, which is an action tremor, whereas this patient has a resting tremor and rigidity. (Choice E) Trihexyphenidyl is an anticholinergic that helps with resting tremor but will not improve bradykinesia and rigidity as well as a dopamine agonist. Educational objective: In patients age <65 with mild to moderate Parkinson disease, dopamine agonists are generally preferred as initial treatment.

stem: A 60-year-old man with long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician due to progressive weakness. Six months ago he started experiencing tingling and numbness in his feet. A few weeks later he experienced similar symptoms in his hands. Over the last 2 months he has been having increasing difficulty rising from a chair, going up stairs, and lifting objects. He does not have slurred speech, difficulty breathing, changes in vision, bowel or bladder dysfunction, or back pain. His neurological examination reveals symmetric, proximal and distal, and upper and lower extremity muscle weakness associated with atrophy. He has reduced vibration, proprioception, and pinprick sensation that is worse in the legs compared to his arms.
