His reflexes are diminished in the upper extremities and absent in the lower extremities. Plantar responses are flexor bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient is likely presenting with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy (CIDP). CIDP is an acquired inflammatory disorder classically presenting with progressive, symmetric, proximal, and distal muscle weakness along with distal sensory loss. Symptoms develop over >8 weeks, which differentiates it from AIDP/Guillain-Barr. Characteristics include diminished/absent reflexes and albuminocytologic dissociation on LP. (Choice A) ALS involves both upper and lower motor neuron signs; this patient lacks hyperreflexia or Babinski signs. (Choice C) Diabetic polyneuropathy is usually predominantly distal and very slowly progressive over years; it wouldn't typically cause this degree of proximal weakness in this timeframe. (Choice D) Guillain-Barr (AIDP) has a much more rapid onset (nadir in 3-4 weeks). (Choice E) Lambert-Eaton involves proximal weakness that improves with activity; reflexes are often absent but sensory function is preserved. Educational objective: CIDP presents with progressive weakness, sensory loss, and absent reflexes developing over >8 weeks.

stem: A 76-year-old man is brought to the physician by his son for unsteadiness and several near-falls over the last 2 weeks. The patient has been less interactive lately and prefers to stay in his room. His symptoms have been slowly worsening over the last 2 weeks. He has had no recent illness, fever, chills, or headaches. His medical problems include mild dementia, ischemic stroke without significant residual deficit, and seizure disorder. His medications include aspirin, phenytoin, levetiracetam, and vitamin D. He was recently started on omeprazole for reflux symptoms. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a narrow-based, unsteady gait with poor balance. His speech is slightly slurred. The patient has horizontal nystagmus and poor coordination with rapid alternating movements and finger-to-nose maneuvers bilaterally. His strength and sensation are intact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient's presentation suggests phenytoin toxicity. Early signs include horizontal nystagmus and gait unsteadiness, followed by slurred speech and lethargy. This patient recently started omeprazole, which inhibits cytochrome P450 and leads to increased serum phenytoin levels. (Choice A) BPPV presents with vertigo provoked by head movements. (Choice B) Cerebellar stroke is usually acute in onset. (Choice C) Depression does not cause nystagmus or slurred speech. (Choice E) Vitamin B12 deficiency causes symmetric peripheral neuropathy and loss of vibration/position sense. Educational objective: Phenytoin toxicity presents with horizontal nystagmus, ataxia, and slurred speech; it can be caused by drug-drug interactions (eg, omeprazole inhibiting CYP450).

stem: A 20-year-old college student comes to the office for evaluation of a recent head injury. Two weeks ago, he sustained a blow to the head with loss of consciousness while playing football. He had headache, mild confusion, and dizziness for several days after the injury, but these symptoms have since resolved. The patient has resumed his schoolwork in the past week and is performing at his prior academic level. Comprehensive neurological examination and computerized cognitive testing are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding this patient's return to play?
choice_d: Return to play after brain MRI
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with sports-related concussion. Athletes with concussion should be removed from play until symptoms resolve. They subsequently benefit from a 6-day graduated return to play protocol involving stepwise increases in physical activity while monitoring for recurrence of symptoms. (Choice A) Retirement from contact sports is considered for those with recurrent concussions and persistent abnormalities. (Choices C and E) There is no set time frame; the key is remaining asymptomatic through a graduated protocol. (Choice D) MRI is only for persistent deficits. Educational objective: Athletes with concussion must be symptom-free before beginning a graduated return to play protocol.

stem: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician for excessive daytime sleepiness. Over the last year he has experienced nighttime sleep disturbances, including dream-enacting behaviors such as talking, yelling, punching, kicking, and jumping from the bed. His mood has changed and he is now frequently depressed and anxious. The patient has noticed increasing difficulty with his sense of smell and no longer enjoys a morning cup of coffee. His bowel movements have also become less regular and he is frequently constipated. He has no headaches, changes in vision, trouble swallowing, slurred speech, numbness, weakness, tremors, or difficulty walking. The patient's BMI is 35 kg/m. His Mini-Mental State Examination is normal. He has a diminished sense of smell on "scratch and sniff" testing. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
explanation: This patient has non-motor symptoms of early idiopathic Parkinson disease (PD). Certain non-motor symptoms can be seen years before the onset of motor symptoms; these include REM sleep behavior disorder (dream-enacting behaviors), mood disturbance (depression/anxiety), anosmia (loss of smell), and constipation. More than 75% of patients with REM sleep behavior disorder subsequently develop PD or other alpha-synucleinopathies. (Choice A) Cerebellar degeneration involves ataxia and intention tremor. (Choice C) Hypothyroidism is a rare cause of anosmia and doesn't cause REM sleep behavior disorder. (Choice D) Midbrain infarction involves oculomotor abnormalities. (Choice E) OSA presents with daytime somnolence and snoring, but not anosmia or REM sleep behavior disorder. Educational objective: Non-motor symptoms (REM sleep behavior disorder, anosmia, constipation) can suggest early PD before motor symptoms appear.

stem: A 70-year-old man comes to the office due to trouble sleeping. He has experienced a progressively worsening urge to move his legs when he watches television at night; the urge persists when he goes to bed and often prevents him from getting to sleep. The sensation to move his legs is not present during the day and disappears when he gets up and walks. There is no associated lower extremity numbness, tingling, or weakness. Medical history is notable only for mild hypertension treated with lisinopril. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This patient has restless legs syndrome (RLS). Iron deficiency is commonly associated with RLS, and serum ferritin should be measured in all patients as supplementation for levels <75 ug/L may alleviate symptoms. (Choice B) Pramipexole is used for patients refractory to conservative therapy and iron replacement. (Choice C) SSRIs may provoke or worsen RLS. (Choice E) Polysomnography is not necessary to diagnose RLS. Educational objective: Restless legs syndrome is characterized by an urge to move the legs relieved by movement; it is commonly associated with iron deficiency.

stem: An 85-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with headache and right-sided weakness. Six months ago, the patient had an intracerebral hemorrhage into the right occipital lobe. Past medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She was treated for locally invasive breast cancer 7 years ago. Her blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows right hemiparesis with right facial droop, dysarthria, and right hemisensory loss. Noncontrast CT of the head reveals a moderate-sized, left frontoparietal lobar hemorrhage with mass effect. MRI shows no enhancement or acute infarction. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
explanation: This patient has a recurrent lobar intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), which is highly suggestive of cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA). CAA is due to amyloid infiltration of cerebral blood vessels, making them fragile; it is a common cause of spontaneous lobar (cortical) ICH in the elderly (>75). (Choice A) AVM hemorrhage usually occurs in younger patients. (Choice C) Hypertensive hemorrhages typically occur in deep structures (basal ganglia, thalamus, pons). (Choice D) Metastatic disease typically shows enhancement on MRI. (Choice E) Ruptured berry aneurysm causes subarachnoid hemorrhage, not intraparenchymal lobar hemorrhage. Educational objective: Amyloid angiopathy is a common cause of recurrent lobar intracerebral hemorrhage in elderly patients.

stem: A 58-year-old man comes to the office with reports of visual disturbances over the past several weeks. He describes multiple episodes of bluish tinting of his vision and a sensation of "lights becoming too bright," which last a few hours and improve spontaneously. He has had no headache, eye pain, loss of vision, or focal weakness. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and erectile dysfunction. His medications include lisinopril, amlodipine, furosemide, insulin detemir, and as-needed sildenafil. Funduscopy shows few microaneurysms but is otherwise unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current visual symptoms?
explanation: Phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitors like sildenafil can interact with PDE-6 in the retina, causing temporary visual side effects such as bluish tinting (cyanopsia), blurry vision, and photophobia. (Choice A) Diabetic retinopathy causes floaters or vision loss but not bluish tinting. (Choice B) Macular degeneration results in central vision loss/tunnel vision. (Choice E) TIAs cause vision loss (amaurosis fugax) but not color changes. Educational objective: Sildenafil can cause temporary dose-dependent visual side effects like bluish tinting due to interaction with PDE-6 in the retina.

stem: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician with foot pain for several months. Pain occurs in the ball of her right foot between the 3rd and 4th toes. It is especially intense when she wears high heels or drives. She often has the sensation of stepping on a marble just beneath her toes. She has no history of foot trauma and the pain does not bother her at night. Unilateral pain is found on deep palpation at the base of the web space between the 3rd and 4th toes. Foot sensation and X-ray are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with Morton's neuroma (interdigital nerve compression), often caused by repetitive injury from wearing high-heeled shoes. Patients feel burning pain and the sensation of "walking on a marble" between the 3rd and 4th metatarsals. (Choice A) Charcot joint involves joint degeneration with swelling/erythema. (Choice B) Diabetic neuropathy involves symmetric impaired sensation. (Choice C) Stress fractures show point tenderness over the bone; this patient's symptoms lasted months and would be visible on X-ray. (Choice E) Plantar fasciitis causes heel pain. Educational objective: Morton's neuroma is a painful enlargement of the plantar digital nerve causing forefoot pain and a "marble" sensation.

stem: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weakness and pain in her left hand for the past 3 weeks. Her other medical problems include left-sided breast cancer for which she underwent lumpectomy and radiation therapy 1 year ago. Examination shows pain to palpation of the medial forearm and hand and weakness throughout the muscles of her left hand (4/5). There is mild ptosis on the left and the left pupil is 3 mm (right pupil 4 mm). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
choice_a: Brachial plexopathy related to previous radiation therapy
choice_b: Brachial plexopathy related to cancer invasion
explanation: This patient's lower brachial plexopathy (medial forearm/hand involvement) combined with Horner's syndrome (ptosis/miosis) is highly suggestive of direct cancer invasion. Radiation-induced plexopathy typically affects the upper plexus and is less painful. (Choice C) Carpal tunnel doesn't cause Horner's. (Choice D) Spinal compression would usually involve more than just one hand and wouldn't explain the Horner's. (Choice E) CRPS involves temperature changes and usually follows trauma. Educational objective: Cancer-induced brachial plexopathy typically involves the lower plexus and is associated with Horner's syndrome and severe pain at onset.

stem: An 82-year-old man is evaluated for dizziness for the past year. The dizziness occurs primarily when he ambulates; it does not bother him while seated or recumbent. He denies spinning, headache, or focal weakness. He has poor hearing and vision. Physical exam shows decreased vibration, position, and light touch sensation below the knees. He cannot walk heel-to-toe, and the Romberg test is positive. Rapid alternating movements are decreased symmetrically. Lab tests (CBC, B12, RPR, Thyroid) are normal. The patient would most likely benefit from which of the following?
explanation: This patient has disequilibrium (dizziness mainly with walking) likely due to a combination of sensory deficits (vision, peripheral neuropathy). Balance training exercises and physical conditioning are the most appropriate management steps. (Choice B) Holter is for arrhythmias, which usually cause presyncope. (Choice C) Meclizine is for vertigo (spinning), which this patient denies. (Choice E) Tight control in the elderly can worsen dizziness due to hypoglycemic episodes. Educational objective: Dizziness in the elderly is often multifactorial (disequilibrium); balance training is a key intervention.

stem: An 84-year-old woman comes to the office due to a fall. She tripped while walking through a hallway in the evening. She has a history of osteoarthritis, back pain, and osteoporosis. Her medications include acetaminophen, docusate, calcium, vitamin D, and alendronate. Physical exam shows normal muscle strength and intact sensations. X-rays show no fractures. Which of the following is the best next step to reduce this patient's risk for further falls?
explanation: Sensory disturbances, especially impaired vision, are a common cause of falls in the elderly. Visual acuity testing is part of the initial multifactorial fall prevention assessment. (Choice B) Cognitive impairment is a risk factor, but a fall in a dark hallway is more suggestive of vision issues. (Choice C) Assistive devices can actually increase fall risk in some patients. (Choice E) B12 deficiency causes neuropathy, but her sensory exam was normal. Educational objective: Visual acuity testing is a critical component of fall risk assessment in the elderly.

stem: A 67-year-old woman comes to the office after a recent hospitalization for abrupt onset of right arm weakness and difficulty speaking that resolved completely. Carotid ultrasound showed 60% stenosis in the left internal carotid artery and 50% stenosis in the right internal carotid artery. ECG and telemetry were unrevealing. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Medications include lisinopril, metoprolol, amlodipine, and aspirin. Laboratory results show LDL 110 mg/dL and Triglycerides 240 mg/dL. Which of the following would be the most appropriate next step to prevent future neurovascular events in this patient?
explanation: This patient had a TIA and has moderate carotid stenosis. High-intensity statin therapy is recommended for all patients with clinically significant atherosclerotic vascular disease to prevent future events. (Choice A) CEA is clearly indicated for symptomatic patients with 70-99% stenosis; for 50-69%, women are often managed medically as surgery is less beneficial than in men. (Choice B) Aspirin, clopidogrel, or aspirin+dipyridamole are all options; she is already on aspirin. (Choice E) Warfarin is for cardioembolic sources like Afib. Educational objective: Patients with symptomatic carotid stenosis should receive medical therapy including statins and antiplatelet agents.

stem: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician with left facial numbness and paresthesias for the last 3 days. She is a known intravenous drug user. One month ago, she had an episode of blurry vision in her right eye and vertigo that resolved spontaneously. Examination shows a pale right optic disc, right relative afferent pupillary defect, and reduced sensation on the left side of the face. Motor exam shows increased tone and hyperreflexia in the right upper extremity. MRI of the brain shows multifocal ovoid white matter lesions. Which of the following would be most helpful in confirming the diagnosis in this patient?
explanation: This patient's presentation (optic neuritis, focal deficits disseminated in time and space, and characteristic MRI findings) suggests multiple sclerosis (MS). In atypical cases or to support the diagnosis, lumbar puncture demonstrating oligoclonal IgG bands is performed. Given her IV drug use, endocarditis with emboli is a differential, but emboli typically affect the cortex and wouldn't explain optic neuritis. (Choice E) TEE would look for vegetations but is less helpful for MS. Educational objective: Multiple sclerosis is diagnosed by CNS deficits disseminated in time and space; CSF analysis showing oligoclonal bands supports the diagnosis.

stem: A 66-year-old man with Parkinson disease complains of painful involuntary contractions affecting the toes of both feet in the morning soon after he wakes up. He has been taking immediate-release carbidopa/levodopa twice daily for 5 years. Examination shows a resting tremor and mild rigidity. Which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's current symptoms?
choice_c: Ordering a split night sleep study
choice_d: Switching to long-acting carbidopa/levodopa at night
explanation: This patient is experiencing "wearing-off" symptoms (morning dystonia) due to low dopamine levels overnight. Switching to a long-acting carbidopa/levodopa formulation at night helps maintain steadier dopamine levels. (Choice A) Benztropine is for tremors or drug-induced dystonia. (Choice B) Decreasing the dose would worsen the dystonia. Educational objective: Morning dystonia in Parkinson patients is often due to low dopamine levels overnight and can be treated with long-acting formulations.

stem: A 18-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of headaches for the past 3 months. She says that the headaches occur almost daily, are holo-cranial, and have a pulsatile quality. They are especially bothersome at night. Her BMI is 34 kg/m. Visual field examination and cranial nerves are intact. MRI and MRV of the head reveal an empty sella but no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?
explanation: This patient presents with idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). Diagnosis requires neuroimaging to exclude secondary causes and a lumbar puncture to document elevated opening pressure (>250 mm H2O). Empty sella is a common but non-diagnostic finding. (Choice C) Sumatriptan is for migraines. Educational objective: Idiopathic intracranial hypertension diagnosis requires a lumbar puncture showing elevated opening pressure with normal CSF analysis.

stem: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician with fatigue over the last 2 months. He is so exhausted by the end of the day that he starts "to see double." He has noticed occasional trouble swallowing and frequent coughing while drinking. CT scan of the chest reveals an anterior mediastinal mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient's symptoms (fatigue, diplopia, dysphagia) suggest myasthenia gravis (MG), and the anterior mediastinal mass is most likely a thymoma. 10-15% of MG patients have a thymoma. (Choice A) Lymphomas cause B-symptoms (fever, weight loss). (Choice C) Small cell lung cancer is associated with Lambert-Eaton, which rarely involves ocular symptoms. Educational objective: Thymoma is the most common cause of an anterior mediastinal mass and is frequently associated with myasthenia gravis.

stem: A 74-year-old man is brought to the physician by his son for forgetfulness. Over the last 2 years, the patient has missed several important appointments, often forgets to take his medication, and has limited his social interaction. Two months ago, he got lost in the neighborhood he has lived in for the last 20 years. The patient says he is "fine and in good spirits." He is a retired mathematics professor. Neurologic examination, including gait assessment, is unremarkable. His mini-mental state examination score is 26/30. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This highly educated patient likely has Alzheimer dementia despite his normal mini-mental state examination (MMSE) score as he has symptoms of cognitive dysfunction (eg, memory loss, visuospatial impairment) that are affecting his daily activities (eg, managing medications). An MMSE score <24 is 87% sensitive and 82% specific for dementia; however, individuals with very mild dementia or those who are highly educated with dementia can have normal scores. One study showed that in individuals without cognitive dysfunction, the median MMSE score is 29 with ge9 years of education and 26 with 5-8 years of education. Some experts suggest the cutoff for dementia be increased to a score of 27 in older individuals with a college education. (Choice B) This patient's lack of fluctuating cognition, Parkinson symptoms, and visual hallucinations makes dementia with Lewy bodies less likely. (Choice C) Patients with late-life depression can have a normal MMSE score, but they usually have somatic symptoms and changes in mood, which are not evident in this patient. (Choices D and E) By definition, normal aging and mild cognitive impairment should not significantly impair daily activities. Educational objective: Individuals with very mild dementia or those who are highly educated with dementia can have normal mini-mental state examination scores.

stem: A 50-year-old woman comes to the office due to both of her feet feeling "asleep." Her symptoms have progressively worsened over the last 2 years and she occasionally stumbles while walking. She has no fatigue, weakness, pain, or other neurologic symptoms. The patient considers herself to be in good health and has no known medical problems. She has an average diet and does not drink alcohol. Vital signs and general physical examination are within normal limits. BMI is 30{kg/m}^{2} Neurologic examination indicates bilateral decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick extending downward from the ankles. Ankle reflexes are absent and muscle strength is normal. Which of the following would confirm the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?
explanation: This obese patient likely has diabetic neuropathy, the most common cause of peripheral neuropathy in adults. Up to 18% of patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus have evidence of nerve damage at the time of diagnosis, suggesting that prediabetes is associated with neuropathy. In addition, up to 50% of patients diagnosed with idiopathic peripheral neuropathy have prediabetes. Early detection is important as the incidence of diabetic neuropathy increases with time, and complications (eg, foot ulcer, Charcot arthropathy) may follow. Patients typically have numbness, paresthesias, and/or burning of the feet that insidiously spread in a stocking-glove distribution. Initially, sensation involving pain/temperature and vibration/proprioception may be impaired. Patients can also have diminished or absent ankle reflexes early in the disease. Frank muscle weakness may be a later finding in severe cases. (Choice A) Folic acid deficiency may cause megaloblastic anemia, but it is not typically associated with neurologic abnormalities such as peripheral neuropathy. (Choice C) Plasma cell dyscrasias are usually seen in older adults with symptoms of anemia, bone pain, fatigue, and renal disease. Peripheral neuropathy may occur due to associated amyloidosis but is not usually evident at the time of diagnosis. This patient's age and lack of these symptoms make plasma cell dyscrasias less likely. (Choice D) Long-standing hypothyroidism may result in a distal symmetric sensory neuropathy. However, this patient does not have other manifestations, such as fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, constipation, or bradycardia. (Choice E) Heavy metals can cause peripheral neuropathy; however, exposure is uncommon and neuropathy classically presents with extensor weakness (eg, wrist drop, ankle drop) and is rarely the sole symptom (eg, abdominal pain, myalgias, and cognitive difficulties noted in lead poisoning). In the absence of known exposure to heavy metals, more common causes (eg, diabetes) should be ruled out. Educational objective: Diabetic neuropathy is the most common cause of peripheral neuropathy in adults and may be associated with prediabetes. Early signs can include impaired sensation (eg, pain/temperature, vibration/proprioception) involving the feet and diminished ankle reflexes. Motor weakness may occur in advanced cases.

stem: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician for difficulty falling asleep. He experiences discomfort in the lower extremities and a strong urge to move his legs, which occurs just as he is about to fall asleep. His wife is awakened because of his excessive leg movements. The patient has no headaches, tremors, weakness, or numbness. He has hypertension and takes lisinopril and daily low-dose aspirin. He is a chronic smoker but does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Vital signs and neurological examination are unremarkable. A complete blood count and serum iron studies are normal. Which of the following is the best initial treatment for this patient's condition?
explanation: This patient, with lower-extremity discomfort, urge to move the legs when falling asleep, and nocturnal leg movements, has typical features of restless leg syndrome (RLS). Clinically, RLS is characterized by an irresistible urge to move one's body, typically the legs, to stop uncomfortable or odd sensations. The symptoms are worsened by attempts at relaxation and falling asleep. RLS is more common in middle-aged and older patients, as well as those with chronic kidney disease and/or iron deficiency anemia. First-line treatment in RLS includes dopaminergic agonists (ropinirole, pramipexole), with gabapentin considered in refractory cases. Levodopa may also be considered for patients who only need occasional treatment. Supplemental interventions that may be considered include iron supplementation (if low ferritin), leg massage, warm or cold compresses, sleep hygiene measures, and regular exercise. (Choice A) Benztropine is an anticholinergic drug indicated for the treatment of parkinsonism and drug-induced extrapyramidal disorders. It has not been well studied for use in RLS. (Choice B) Benzodiazepines and opiates are helpful in RLS, but sedation and tolerance limit their use. They are used primarily as second-line therapy or for patients with only occasional symptoms. (Choice C) Clozapine and other dopamine receptor blockers (eg, haloperidol) may not help RLS and could worsen symptoms. (Choice E) Valproic acid has been studied for use in RLS, but evidence is limited and potential toxicity likely outweighs benefit for most patients. Educational objective: Dopaminergic agonists (ropinirole, pramipexole) are the mainstays of treatment for restless leg syndrome.

stem: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician with complaints of poor balance and near-falls over the last 6 months. He recently began using a cane for ambulation. He also reports memory loss during this period and has difficulty handling finances and keeping appointments. The patient has no headache, trauma, visual difficulty, slurred speech, muscle weakness, back pain, or incontinence. His past medical history includes chronic lymphocytic leukemia. He takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has some postural instability on pull-back testing. Gait is slow with short strides. He turns slowly, with several steps. There is no evidence of tremor or rigidity, although he does have increased tone in the lower extremities with brisk reflexes. He scores 24/30 on the Mini-Mental State Examination. The remainder of the physical examination is within normal limits. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain with and without gadolinium shows enlarged ventricles. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient likely has normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). Idiopathic NPH usually occurs in individuals age >60. Secondary NPH can occur in any age group and is usually due to subarachnoid hemorrhage or meningitis leading to impaired cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) absorption. The classic triad of NPH is gait instability, cognitive dysfunction, and urinary incontinence. Patients usually present with a history of falls and complaints of feet being fixed to the floor. Urinary incontinence is a late feature. Gait appears similar to that of Parkinsonism except that in NPH it is more wide based (versus narrow based in Parkinson disease). Increased tone or brisk reflexes in the lower extremities and depressed affect indicate pressure on the frontal and prefrontal cortex from enlarged ventricles. The pull-back test and Mini-Mental State Examination may be abnormal but are nonspecific. Subcortical and frontal dysfunctions are more prominent without cortical dysfunction (eg, aphasia and apraxia). Magnetic resonance is a better imaging technique than computed tomography for evaluation of NPH and shows enlarged ventricles out of proportion to sulcal enlargement. The Miller Fisher test (lumbar tap test) confirms the diagnosis of NPH and also helps select patients for treatment. It involves removing 30-50 mL of cerebrospinal fluid via lumbar tap and observing for symptomatic improvement in gait and cognitive function about an hour after the procedure. NPH treatment involves ventriculoperitoneal shunt placement, with clinical improvement in about 60% of patients. (Choice A) Alzheimer disease presents with a slowly progressive dementia that affects memory out of proportion to other cognitive functioning. Patients also have difficulty with cortical functions (eg, aphasia, apraxia), which is not usually seen in NPH patients. Gait disturbance is usually a late feature. (Choice B) Acute myeloid leukemia, but not chronic lymphocytic leukemia, is a common cause of leptomeningeal carcinomatosis. Carcinomatous meningitis usually presents with both focal (eg, cranial nerve palsies, focal weakness) and global symptoms (eg, headache, nausea, vomiting). Symptoms typically develop acutely, over days to weeks. Examination shows multifocal involvement (eg, diplopia, absent knee reflex). (Choice C) Dementia with Lewy bodies presents with progressive cognitive decline, Parkinsonian features (eg, bradykinesia, cogwheel rigidity), and prominent visual hallucinations. (Choice D) Idiopathic intracranial hypertension usually presents with headaches and papilledema on examination. Lumbar puncture (done after neuroimaging) usually shows high opening pressures (>250 mm H2O). Neuroimaging does not usually show enlarged ventricles, as seen in this patient. Educational objective: The classic triad of normal-pressure hydrocephalus is cognitive dysfunction, gait difficulty, and urinary incontinence. Diagnosis is usually confirmed by magnetic resonance imaging showing enlarged ventricles and symptomatic improvement after removal of 30-50 mL of cerebrospinal fluid via lumbar puncture. Treatment involves ventriculoperitoneal shunting.

stem: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician with the complaint of weakness. He was well until about 3 weeks ago when he had several episodes of diarrhea that lasted 4 days. Seven days ago, he felt shooting pains in his feet and legs followed by bilateral leg weakness. He reports difficulty with ambulation and getting out of a chair. He has no fever, chills, vision changes, dysphagia, bladder or bowel problems, back pain, muscle tenderness, or dark urine. His past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and lovastatin. His blood pressure is 144/86 mm Hg, and pulse is 90/min and regular. Physical examination reveals marked symmetrical weakness of both legs without sensory deficits. Lower-extremity deep-tendon reflexes are absent. There is slight symmetric weakness of his hands, but strength and deep-tendon reflexes of his proximal upper extremities are intact. Cranial nerves are intact. The remainder of the examination is within normal limits. Laboratory results are as follows: Hematocrit 40%, Platelets 260,000/mu L, Leukocytes 7,700/mu L. Sodium 142~mEq/L, Potassium 3.8~mEq/L, Chloride 98~mEq/L, Bicarbonate 26~mEq/L, Creatinine 0.8~mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely finding on cerebrospinal fluid analysis?
explanation: This patient with symmetric, ascending muscle weakness and absent deep-tendon reflexes after recent infectious illness most likely has Guillain-Barr syndrome (GBS). About 10% of patients with GBS present with arm or facial weakness instead of leg weakness. More than 80% of patients complain of paresthesias in the hands and feet; however, sensory examination is frequently normal. About two-thirds of patients complain of severe pain in the back and extremities. Diagnosis is made clinically as well as with lumbar puncture and neurophysiology studies (eg, EMG). Typical lumbar puncture findings include elevated CSF protein with normal WBC count (albuminocytologic dissociation), which is seen in 80-90% of patients within 1 week after onset of symptoms. EMG and nerve conduction studies may show evidence of polyneuropathy. GBS prognosis is generally good. However, nearly 25% of affected individuals require mechanical ventilation and up to 20% of severely affected individuals remain unable to walk 6 months after symptom onset. Treatment involves supportive care plus plasmapheresis or IVIG, which can accelerate recovery. Educational objective: Guillain-Barr syndrome usually presents after recent infectious illness with ascending symmetrical weakness, loss of reflexes, and no significant sensory loss. Diagnosis is made clinically with neurophysiology studies as well as lumbar puncture showing high protein with normal WBC count (90% patients). Treatment is supportive and can be accelerated by plasmapheresis or IVIG.

stem: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician for mild pain, tingling, and numbness in her right hand. The symptoms started 2 weeks ago and are worse at night. She experiences neck pain occasionally but has no shooting or radiating pain. The patient has not had any recent head/neck trauma, headache, muscle weakness, or bowel/bladder incontinence. Her past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and cervical degenerative disk disease. The patient has a 30-pack-year smoking history. She is retired and knits frequently as a hobby. Her blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg and pulse is 88/min. Examination of the right hand reveals decreased sensation to pain and temperature along the ventral aspect of the first 3 digits and the radial half of the fourth digit. Sensation over the thenar eminence is preserved. There is no muscle weakness or atrophy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) as she has subjective pain/paresthesias in the median nerve distribution. Symptoms of CTS are frequently worse at night and can be exacerbated by repetitive/sustained hand movements (eg, knitting). Preservation of sensation over the thenar eminence is highly indicative as the palmar sensory cutaneous branch of the median nerve goes over, not through, the carpal tunnel. Provocative maneuvers such as the Phalen and Tinel tests have limited sensitivity (~60%) and specificity (~70%). CTS is primarily a clinical diagnosis. Nerve conduction studies (NCS) are usually performed during atypical presentations, to evaluate disease severity, and prior to considering surgery (sensitivity 56%-85%, specificity 94%). Electromyography is often done with NCS to differentiate neurogenic versus myopathic weakness. Neither of these studies is necessary in this patient as her symptoms are mild and her presentation is typical of CTS (Choice C). Patients with mild-to-moderate disease can have short-term symptom relief with conservative measures (20%-93% success rate) such as wrist splinting and injectable corticosteroids. Decompressive surgery might result in long-term improvement (75% success rate) and should be considered in patients with severe disease or in those who have failed conservative measures (Choice D). (Choice A) Although this patient has risk factors for stroke (eg, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, smoking), a brain MRI will not likely be useful as her focal sensory deficits follow a median nerve distribution. Patients with lacunar stroke of the thalamus can present with pure sensory loss; however, symptoms/signs typically occur on one side of the body (eg, face, arm, and leg). (Choice B) Cervical radiculopathy can present with pain and paresthesias in the hand; however, symptoms would follow a dermatomal pattern as opposed to a median nerve pattern. Educational objective: Carpal tunnel syndrome is primarily a clinical diagnosis. Electrodiagnostic studies are usually performed during atypical presentations, to evaluate disease severity, and prior to considering surgery. Mild-to-moderate cases can be treated conservatively (eg, wrist splinting, injectable corticosteroids).

stem: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician after several months of headaches. She describes them as moderate intensity and occurring frequently, now daily. She occasionally hears a noise similar to wind blowing during the headaches. The patient has taken escalating doses of over-the-counter painkillers with some relief. She smokes marijuana occasionally. Her blood pressure is 132/80 mm Hg and heart rate is 87/min On neurologic examination, there is no muscle weakness or sensory loss. Deep-tendon reflexes are normal. The neck is supple. Funduscopic findings (as shown) are the same in both eyes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient has the following characteristic features of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), or pseudotumor cerebri: Chronic pulsatile headache exacerbated by lying flat and improved by sitting up; "Whooshing" or wind-like tinnitus; Papilledema with blurring of the optic disk margins. Other common features of IIH may include blurry vision or vision loss and horizontal binocular diplopia. IIH is typically seen in young obese women and is believed to be caused by either excess cerebrospinal fluid production or inadequate absorption. Neuroimaging (ie, MRI) should be performed to exclude other causes of increased intracranial pressure (eg, metastatic lesions, venous sinus thrombosis, obstructive hydrocephalus) but will usually show only normal findings or minor nonspecific abnormalities. If imaging is normal, the diagnosis can be confirmed with lumbar puncture showing elevated opening pressure (>200-250 mm H2O). Initial management for most cases of IIH is acetazolamide and weight loss. Some patients will require the addition of loop diuretics, and surgery is occasionally needed to relieve intracranial pressure. The primary risk of untreated IIH is loss of vision due to optic nerve injury. (Choice B) Medication overuse headache typically occurs after daily exposure (>15 days/month) to an analgesic medication (especially opiates). It is not associated with papilledema. (Choice C) Meniere disease, or endolymphatic hydrops, is a disorder of the inner ear that results from overproduction or under-absorption of endolymph. Patients will typically develop tinnitus in one ear associated with ear fullness and progressive sensorineural hearing loss and vertigo. Papilledema, blurry vision, and headache are not associated with Meniere disease. (Choice D) Multiple sclerosis is a relapsing-remitting autoimmune disease caused by demyelinating lesions in the central nervous system that are disseminated in space and time. Attacks can manifest as optic neuritis, characterized by acute headache with unilateral blurry vision and papilledema/papillitis. Chronic headaches and bilateral papilledema are not typical of acute optic neuritis from multiple sclerosis. (Choice E) Open-angle glaucoma accounts for 90% of glaucoma cases in the United States. It presents clinically with gradual painless loss of vision rather than acute attacks. Funduscopy may show characteristic optic nerve changes (such as increased cup-to-disk ratio). Tonometry usually shows elevated intraocular pressures. Papilledema is not usually seen with open-angle glaucoma but can be seen with closed-angle glaucoma due to very high intraocular pressures. Educational objective: Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri) is characterized by chronic pulsatile headaches, often associated with "whooshing" tinnitus. The headaches are worsened by lying flat. Funduscopy should be performed to evaluate for the presence of papilledema, which suggests elevated intracranial pressure. If neuroimaging is negative, the diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring opening pressure on lumbar puncture.

stem: A 67-year-old man seeks medical attention because of unsteadiness and near-falls over the last several weeks. He has noticed some numbness in his hand and urinary urgency more frequently than what he usually experiences. He also describes many months of neck pain, shoulder discomfort, and lower back pain. There is no history of neck or back trauma. He has had no fever, chills, or weight loss. He denies any headaches, vertigo, vision loss, or difficulty swallowing. He rides an indoor exercise bicycle for 45 minutes three times a week and goes for 3-4 hour outdoor rides on his bicycle both weekend days. He had a normal colonoscopy within the past five years. He takes no medications other than a daily multivitamin. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.0 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 155/84 mm Hg, pulse is 85/min, and respirations are 14/min There is 4/5 muscle strength in his bilateral lower extremities with 3+ reflexes. Upper extremity examination is normal except for mildly decreased sensations in both hands. No muscle atrophy or fasciculations are present. His Mini Mental Status Exam score is 29/30. Laboratory data reveal: Hemoglobin 13.5~g/dL, Platelets 210,000/mm^{3}, Calcium 9.0~mg/dL, Creatinine 1.6~mg/dL, ESR 15~mm/hr, Vitamin B12 400~pg/mL. EKG shows sinus rhythm with left ventricular hypertrophy. Chest X-ray shows mild cardiomegaly but clear lung fields. A cervical spine series demonstrates degenerative changes in the C5, 6, and 7 areas. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Cervical spondylosis is a progressive degenerative process of the cervical vertebral bodies and discs (most common in adults age >55) that can result in disc herniation, osteophyte formation, and hypertrophy of the posterior longitudinal ligament and ligament flava. These processes can lead to cervical spinal canal stenosis, mechanical spinal cord compression (in about 5-10% of individuals), and spinal cord ischemia (due to compression of the arterial and venous supplies of the cord). Flexion and extension of the neck can exacerbate cord compression while extension of the neck (which may occur when this patient bicycles) reduces the diameter of the spinal canal and causes inward buckling of the ligamentum flavum. Both MRI and CT can be used to diagnose cervical cord compression. MRI is preferred since it provides better intramedullary detail of the spinal cord while CT gives better images of bone and calcified tissues. There should be careful clinical and anatomic correlation since there is a high frequency of MRI abnormalities of the cervical spine in asymptomatic older individuals. Conservative treatment with cervical immobilization is indicated for mild myelopathy while surgical decompression is reserved for patients who fail conservative measures, severe myelopathy or progressing deficits, or acute deterioration with cord compression. (Choice A) Both amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and cervical cord compression can occur in older individuals and produce a combination of upper and lower motor neuron findings. ALS generally has lower motor neuron deficits and fasciculations in the lower extremities and cranial muscles, while cervical cord compression has deficits isolated to the affected dermatome. ALS usually does not cause sensory deficits while cervical cord compression may have subtle or absent sensory deficits. This patient does exhibit some sensory deficits, which would make ALS unlikely. An electromyogram, which usually documents denervation in ALS, may be helpful to distinguish between the two disorders. (Choice C) Chronic or subacute Guillain Barr syndrome can present as progressive upper and lower extremity weakness, but reflexes are lost or diminished in contrast to the hyperreflexia seen in this patient. (Choice D) The combination of gait impairment and urinary symptoms may suggest normal pressure hydrocephalus; however, this patient does not have cognitive dysfunction which is usually seen with normal pressure hydrocephalus. (Choice E) Transverse myelitis usually occurs in a younger population and presents with a segmental cord syndrome, which is not present in this case. Spinal cord MRI and cerebral spinal fluid analysis are required for diagnosis of transverse myelitis. Educational objective: Cervical spondylotic myelopathy is a relatively common and potentially treatable cause of progressive disability in older adults. This condition often presents with upper motor neuron signs in the lower extremities and lower motor neuron signs in the upper extremities. MRI is the diagnostic study of choice.

stem: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of difficulty walking for the past 1 week. His medical problems include hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and osteoarthritis of the left hip. He underwent gastric bypass surgery 5 weeks ago for morbid obesity. Neurological examination shows a left foot drop with strength in the left leg as follows: dorsiflexion 1/5, foot eversion 2/5, foot inversion 5/5, and plantar flexion 5/5. Sensory examination shows decreased pin prick sensation over the dorsum of the left foot. The remainder of the neurological examination is unremarkable. Which of the following sites has this patient most likely injured?
explanation: This patient has most likely injured the left common peroneal nerve in the fibular head region, resulting in a peroneal neuropathy. Risk factors include prolonged immobilization (e.g., surgery or hospitalization), leg crossing, squatting, and leg casting; especially when combined with significant weight loss (e.g., gastric bypass surgery in this patient). Patients typically present with foot drop and paresthesias and/or sensory loss involving the dorsum of the foot and lateral shin. Patients tend to trip over the affected foot and compensate by flexing the hip while walking, leading to a "steppage" gait. Examination usually shows weakness on foot dorsiflexion and eversion, and decreased sensation in the dorsum of the foot. However, there is usually a normal Achilles reflex with normal foot inversion and plantar flexion. Treatment involves removing the pressure on the nerve, an ankle-foot orthosis splint to keep the foot dorsiflexed, and physical therapy to improve walking. However, the treatments have variable results with little recovery of function in most cases. (Choice B) A mid-thigh nerve injury may involve the femoral nerve leading to acute thigh weakness and numbness, which this patient does not have. (Choice C) A sciatic notch nerve injury may result in sciatica, which usually causes pain in the sciatic nerve distribution and sensory loss involving both the peroneal and sural nerves. This patient only has peroneal involvement, which makes this less likely. (Choice D) A tarsal tunnel nerve injury compresses the posterior tibial nerve. Symptoms are mainly sensory (i.e., burning pain of the foot and heel, paresthesias, and sensory loss in the sole) with rare foot weakness. This patient's foot weakness makes this unlikely. (Choice E) Lumbar vertebral foraminal nerve root injury causes a lumbar radiculopathy. L5 radiculopathy is associated with weakness of ankle inversion and toe flexion, sensory loss more localized to the big toe region, and a radicular pattern of pain. Educational objective: Peroneal neuropathy is usually due to an injury of the nerve at the fibular head and typically presents with foot drop and paresthesias of the dorsum of the foot. Patients usually have normal reflexes and foot inversion, which can help differentiate peroneal neuropathy from other causes of neuropathy in the lower extremity.

stem: A 33-year-old woman with no past medical history comes to the emergency department complaining of progressive leg weakness and difficulty walking that started 2 days ago. Yesterday she had difficulty with urination. Two weeks ago, she had an upper respiratory tract infection and diarrhea that has since resolved. She is a vegan and takes daily multivitamin supplements. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cranial nerve examination is unremarkable. Strength is 5/5 in the upper extremities and 2/5 in the lower extremities. Reflexes are 2+ in the arms but absent in the legs with decreased tone. Rectal tone is diminished. There is no response to plantar cutaneous stimulation in the big toes bilaterally. Superficial abdominal reflexes are absent. There is sensory loss to pain, temperature, vibration, and proprioception of both lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient's presentation suggests transverse myelitis (TM), a rare inflammatory disorder causing segmental spinal cord injury. Most cases of TM are idiopathic, likely due to an autoimmune process following a viral infection (50% of cases). Patients present initially with spinal shock - lower-extremity weakness, flaccidity, areflexia, and absent Babinski sign. There will be a sensory level to all primary sensory modalities. Bowel and bladder dysfunction are present. Some patients also complain of a "band-like" squeezing pain. After 1 week, patients usually develop spasticity, hyperreflexia, Babinski sign, and clonus. Diagnosis is suggested by magnetic resonance imaging with contrast, which shows enhancing cord segments with surrounding edema. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis usually shows elevated protein, moderate lymphocytosis, normal glucose, and no oligoclonal bands. Treatment is typically supportive (physical therapy). Intravenous corticosteroids can sometimes help patients with an autoimmune component of the disease. Recovery usually occurs within 3 months, with up to 40% of patients experiencing some residual disability. (Choice A) Cauda equina syndrome affects the lumbosacral roots as they exit the spinal cord and is usually caused by a herniated disk or tumor. Clinically, patients will present with severe unilateral pain in the saddle region that radiates down to the legs with associated asymmetrical lower-extremity weakness (proximal and distal). The presence of significant bowel/bladder/sphincter symptoms clinically distinguishes cauda equina syndrome from Guillain-Barr syndrome (GBS); the presence of severe shooting (lancinating) pain distinguishes it from TM. (Choice B) TM can mimic GBS in the setting of spinal shock, as reflexes and Babinski sign will be absent. However, patients with GBS will not have bowel/bladder symptoms or a sensory loss below a spinal cord segment. (Choice C) Spinal cord infarction usually presents with abrupt onset (minutes to hours) of back pain, weakness (and possibly paralysis), loss of sensation and reflexes, and autonomic dysfunction. Onset of symptoms (days) and antecedent viral illness are more suggestive of TM. (Choice D) Vitamin B12 deficiency results in slowly progressive weakness, ataxia, and neuropsychiatric disturbances. This patient's acute onset of symptoms is less consistent with cobalamin deficiency. Educational objective: Acute onset of weakness and sensory loss below a segmental spinal level, paresthesias, and bowel/bladder/sphincter dysfunction suggest transverse myelitis. Magnetic resonance imaging with contrast shows enhancing cord segments with surrounding edema. Treatment is mainly supportive and can include intravenous corticosteroids.

stem: A 65-year-old man is brought to the office due to a 2-year history of progressive cognitive decline. The patient has difficulty finding the right words and recognizing faces, and he has stopped driving because he gets lost on the streets. Over the past 6 months, he has had frequent falls, dizziness on standing, and urinary incontinence. The patient increasingly requires his wife's help to perform activities of daily living. His seated blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg and standing blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Pulse increases from 90/min when sitting to 100/min when standing. Mini-mental state examination score is 16/30 The patient's face appears masked, but the rest of the cranial nerves are intact. He has bilaterally symmetrical cogwheel rigidity and bradykinesia in the arms but no tremor. His gait is slow and wide-based. The remainder of the patient's neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Basic blood work and spinal fluid analysis results are unremarkable. An MRI of the brain reveals diffuse cerebral and pontocerebellar atrophy that is out of proportion to the patient's stated age. A routine electroencephalogram shows diffuse slowing. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient likely has multiple system atrophy, a type of Parkinson-plus syndrome. Parkinson-plus syndromes make up approximately 10%-15% of cases of parkinsonism and can generally be distinguished from idiopathic Parkinson disease by the rapid onset of symptoms, symmetric neurologic findings (eg, bradykinesia, rigidity), absent tremor, early autonomic dysfunction (eg, urinary incontinence, orthostatic hypotension), and poor response to dopamine agonists (Choice C). The 3 most common Parkinson-plus syndromes include multiple system atrophy, progressive supranuclear palsy, and corticobasal degeneration, and each has a unique set of features. The diagnosis of multiple system atrophy is clinical, incorporating a combination of core findings that include akinetic-rigid parkinsonism, autonomic failure, and cerebellar ataxia (eg, wide-based, unsteady gait). Brain MRI may reveal nonspecific atrophy of the putamen, middle cerebellar peduncle, or pons but is mainly useful in excluding alternate conditions (eg, infarction, tumor). (Choice A) Dementia with Lewy bodies may present with cognitive impairment, parkinsonism, and autonomic dysfunction. However, other core features (eg, visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition/alertness) are not evident in this patient. (Choice B) Frontotemporal dementia typically presents with changes in personality/behavior (eg. emotional blunting, social disinhibition) and language abnormalities (eg, aphasia). Neuroimaging often reveals frontal and temporal lobe atrophy. (Choice E) Sporadic spongiform encephalopathy (Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease) is an infectious prion-mediated neurodegenerative disorder characterized by rapidly progressive (<1 year) dementia and myoclonus. Educational objective: Parkinson-plus syndromes (eg, multiple system atrophy, progressive supranuclear palsy, corticobasal degeneration) can generally be distinguished from idiopathic Parkinson disease by the rapid onset of symptoms, symmetric neurologic findings, absence of tremor, early autonomic dysfunction, and poor response to levodopa. The hallmark features of multiple system atrophy include akinetic-rigid parkinsonism, autonomic failure, and cerebellar ataxia.

stem: A 25-year-old primigravida at the 32nd week of pregnancy comes to the physician with increasing headaches. She describes the headaches as severe in intensity, unilateral, throbbing, and associated with light sensitivity and nausea. They currently occur once or twice a week. She has had similar headaches for the last several years that usually improve with ibuprofen and bed rest. However, she does not want to take any unsafe drugs. The patient has tried massage, relaxation, and techniques to improve her sleep without significant improvement. She has no other medical problems. Her current medications include an oral multivitamin. Vital signs and examination are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?
explanation: This patient has typical migraine headaches, with management complicated by pregnancy. Patients with severe symptoms or who are refractory to non-drug therapies (eg, hydration, massage, ice packs) should receive medications with minimal fetal risk. Acetaminophen is preferred due to its low risk of adverse events. Patients not responding to acetaminophen alone may benefit from adding an antiemetic (eg, metoclopramide), codeine, or caffeine/butalbital. However, butalbital and codeine should be used sparingly to avoid medication overuse headache. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as naproxen can be used as a 2nd option in patients not responding to acetaminophen but should be used only in brief courses; they are associated with fetal toxicity in the 1st and 3rd trimesters (Choice C). Stronger opioids (eg, oxycodone) are 3rd-line therapy but can be habit-forming and possibly worsen nausea/vomiting and constipation during pregnancy. Parenteral antiemetics can also be considered acutely and can be used as monotherapy for migraines. (Choice B) Ergotamine is contraindicated during pregnancy due to the risk of inducing hypertonic uterine contractions and vasoconstriction, which can lead to adverse fetal effects. (Choice D) The "triptans" (eg, sumatriptan) can be considered in patients who are refractory to other therapies. However, some studies have shown an increased risk of vasoconstriction of uteroplacental vessels, increased uterotonic activity, preterm delivery, and low birth weight. (Choice E) Topiramate has been associated with adverse events and is contraindicated during pregnancy. Beta blockers (eg, propranolol) are generally preferred for patients requiring prophylaxis. Educational objective: Acetaminophen is the preferred medication for migraines during pregnancy due to its low risk of adverse events. Other options in patients not responding to acetaminophen include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (2nd trimester), opioids, and antiemetics.

stem: A 74-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine checkup. She has had difficulty with her memory that has worsened over the past year. She sometimes forgets important appointments, including doctors' appointments. The patient often forgets to take her daily pills. It has also become difficult for her to remember the names of new people she meets, and she often has to write them down. The patient drives, shops, and pays her bills independently. She admits that she has had bouts of loneliness since her husband died 2 years ago; however, she still enjoys socializing with friends when she has the energy. The patient has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and left knee osteoarthritis. Her mother died of a stroke, and her father died of Alzheimer disease. The patient's blood pressure is 132/78 mm Hg and pulse is 76/min. BMI is 29{kg/m}^{2}. Neurological examination shows no focal deficits. She scores a 25/30 on the Montreal Cognitive Assessment. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with mild cognitive impairment (MCI), also known as mild neurocognitive disorder. MCI is characterized by cognitive impairment that does not meet criteria for dementia (ie, major neurocognitive disorder) but is more severe than the mild deficits found in normal aging (Choice E). Patients with MCI have noticeable cognitive impairments but are generally able to compensate for their deficits (eg, written reminders) and function independently. One of the most widely used tools to assess for MCI and dementia is the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA). Scores of <26 are highly sensitive for MCI or dementia; however, the MoCA possesses only moderate specificity. MCI is found in 2 subtypes: amnestic (ie, primarily memory impairment) and nonamnestic MCI. Amnestic MCI is twice as prevalent as nonamnestic forms; amnestic MCI more frequently evolves into Alzheimer disease. (Choices A and B) The diagnosis of dementia requires evidence of progressive cognitive decline accompanied by functional impairment in activities of daily living (ADLs); this patient demonstrates independence with ADLs and so does not meet the criteria for dementia. Alzheimer disease frequently presents with prominent early amnestic symptoms whereas dementia with Lewy bodies may present with fluctuating attention/arousal, visual hallucinations, and REM sleep behavior disorder. (Choice C) Although major depressive disorder frequently accompanies cognitive impairment in elderly patients, this patient lacks key features of this disorder (eg, anhedonia, decreased interest in activities). Educational objective: Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) is characterized by impaired cognition with preserved functioning and independence of activities of daily living.

stem: A 45-year-old woman from Texas comes to the physician with sudden onset of left-sided facial drooping. She first noticed the facial droop while eating Christmas dinner with her family last night. She has also experienced mild drooling from the left side of her mouth. She has no other complaints. The patient has no recent illnesses, travel, rashes, or tick bites. Her other medical problems include hypertension and mild obesity. Her medications include lisinopril and chlorthalidone. Temperature is 36.5 C (97.7 F), blood pressure is 138/85 mm Hg, and pulse is 72/min. The patient has facial asymmetry, drooping of the left angle of her mouth, and loss of the left nasolabial fold. She is unable to close her left eyelid fully, wrinkle her forehead or nose, inflate her left cheek, or show her teeth. The remainder of the examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with Bell's palsy, an acute peripheral facial nerve paralysis likely due to herpes simplex virus activation in most cases. This patient's sudden onset without other associated symptoms makes Bell's palsy most likely. Nearly 70%-85% of patients recover within 3 weeks, but many studies suggest that prednisone given within 3 days of symptom onset significantly improves recovery. Some studies also suggest that adding valacyclovir may help patients with severe facial paralysis. (Choice B) Electromyography is used to monitor the progression of symptoms. However, it is usually performed days to weeks after symptom onset in patients without improvement to document complete facial paresis and determine chances of recovery. (Choice C) Lumbar puncture may help diagnose meningitis or encephalitis. However, this patient's normal mental status and lack of fever, headache, or nuchal rigidity make these diagnoses less likely. (Choice D) Disseminated Lyme disease may present with facial nerve palsy but usually has other associated features (eg, meningitis, radiculopathy, arthralgias). In addition, Lyme disease occurs more commonly in the upper Midwest and northeastern regions of the United States (eg, Connecticut) instead of Texas. Lyme disease is also more common in the summer months, not in winter. (Choice E) Head MRI is indicated in patients with atypical symptoms/signs, facial twitching or spasm preceding weakness, slow progression of symptoms after 3 weeks, or no symptom improvement after 4 months. Educational objective: Bell's palsy is an acute peripheral facial nerve palsy likely due to herpes simplex virus activation; prednisone given early after symptom onset speeds recovery and enhances outcome.

stem: A 25-year-old man with no past medical history comes to his primary care physician for follow-up after a seizure episode 1 week ago. According to his coworkers, he suddenly lost awareness and began having semi-purposeful movements of his right hand. A few seconds later, he fell and had generalized tonic-clonic movements of his arms and legs. The event lasted about 2 minutes and was followed by at least 20 minutes of confusion and lethargy. The patient woke up in the ambulance and had no memory of the event. He admits that 30 seconds before the seizure he had a feeling of uneasiness in his stomach. He has no history of similar events, head trauma, central nervous system infections, or family history of seizures. He takes no medications at home. He works as an accountant and does not use alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drugs. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. In the emergency department, the patient had a normal laboratory workup, urine drug screen, and noncontrast head computed tomography. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
choice_a: Obtain MRI of the brain and EEG for risk stratification
choice_b: Reassure the patient and follow clinically
choice_c: Refer to epilepsy center for continuous EEG monitoring
choice_d: Refer to therapist for evaluation of psychogenic nonepileptic seizure
explanation: This patient's presentation (localized semi-purposeful movements, loss of awareness, tonic-clonic movements, and amnesia) is most consistent with a complex partial seizure that has generalized. Complex partial seizures are usually preceded by an aura (sensory symptoms). Unprovoked first seizures require neuroimaging studies to identify structural brain abnormality. Brain MRI is more sensitive than CT in identifying lesions such as cortical dysplasias, infarcts, or tumors. EEG may show abnormal waves but can also be normal after a seizure. Abnormal MRI or EEG after a single seizure indicates a high risk of future recurrent seizures. These patients benefit from antiepileptic drugs. Patients with normal studies have a lower risk of recurrent seizures and generally do not require drugs (Choices B and E). (Choice C) Continuous EEG monitoring is used primarily to detect nonconvulsive seizures, which were not seen in this patient. (Choice D) This patient's presentation is consistent with an epileptic event; he requires diagnostic testing to rule out underlying organic disease before assuming he had a psychogenic nonepileptic seizure. Educational objective: A single unprovoked seizure requires investigation with laboratory studies, MRI of the brain, and EEG to rule out underlying organic disease and estimate future seizure risk.

stem: A 70-year-old woman comes to the office after several months of severe pain in her upper back and anterior chest. She used over-the-counter analgesics and a lotion to cope with the pain. The patient stopped using the lotion when it caused a skin rash with blisters. The blisters eventually healed, but she continues to have a severe burning sensation that can be triggered with even a slight touch. The pain interferes with the patient's sleep and daily activities. She has degenerative joint disease and lives independently. The patient's vital signs are normal. Skin examination is unremarkable except for an area of hyperesthesia along the fourth intercostal space. The remainder of the examination is within normal limits. Which of the following medications is the most appropriate therapy for this patient?
explanation: This patient has pain along a dermatomal distribution and history of a rash, suggestive of post-herpetic neuralgia (PHN) from herpes zoster. PHN is defined as persistent pain 4 months after rash onset. Anticonvulsants such as pregabalin or gabapentin are useful in alleviating the pain of PHN and could be considered in this patient. Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) such as nortriptyline and desipramine also have evidence of efficacy but are included in the Beers Criteria for older adults due to side effects. (Choice A) Carbamazepine is the treatment for trigeminal neuralgia; there is no evidence to support its use for PHN. (Choice B) Glucocorticoids have not been proven helpful for PHN. (Choice D) Capsaicin can be used for moderate pain but causes intolerable stinging and is not first-line. (Choice E) Antiviral therapy (valacyclovir) may help if initiated within 72 hours of rash onset; this patient is well beyond that window. Educational objective: Post-herpetic neuralgia (pain persisting months after resolution of the rash) is treated with tricyclic antidepressants, gabapentin, or pregabalin.

stem: A 65-year-old woman recently diagnosed with mild cognitive impairment seeks advice about prevention of dementia. The patient has glaucoma, osteoarthritis, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and osteoporosis. She lives alone and performs all activities of daily living independently. The patient is troubled by her memory impairment but compensates by writing things down and making lists. She has no depression and scores 25/30 on the Mini-Mental Status Examination. The patient's sister developed dementia at age 69 and was recently admitted to a long-term care facility. Her aunt suffered from dementia and died of pneumonia at age 78. Blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg and pulse is 77/min. BMI is 26{kg/m}^{2}. General physical examination, including neurologic examination, shows no abnormalities. Complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, serum thyroid-stimulating hormone, and vitamin B_{12} level are all within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
explanation: Patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) are at increased risk for dementia. There is no FDA-approved pharmacologic treatment for MCI. No supplement (eg, vitamin E) or medication (eg, cholinesterase inhibitors, NSAIDs) has demonstrated efficacy for prevention of cognitive decline in MCI. However, exercise should be recommended as studies reported positive effects on global cognition, executive function, and attention. Cognitively stimulating activities and active social engagement can also slow progression. (Choices A, B, and C) There is no consistent evidence for the benefit of NSAIDs or cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil) in preventing progression from MCI to dementia. Memantine is indicated for moderate to severe Alzheimer disease, not MCI. (Choice E) There is no consistent evidence that vitamin E prevents cognitive decline in MCI, though it may slow progression in established mild-to-moderate AD. Educational objective: Higher levels of physical exercise, cognitive activities, and active social interactions are associated with a decrease in the rate of decline in cognitive impairment in patients at risk for dementia.

stem: A 67-year-old man comes to an urgent care clinic with skin rash and malaise over the last several days. He has a history of hypertension and suffered an ischemic stroke 2 years earlier. One month ago, he had an episode of new-onset tonic-clonic seizures and was hospitalized for 2 days. MR imaging of the brain during that admission showed no intracranial mass lesion. Electroencephalogram done at that time was normal. His current medications include aspirin, rosuvastatin, valsartan, amlodipine, and phenytoin. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. The patient's temperature is 38.2 C (100.8 F), blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 85/min. Oral examination shows mild pharyngeal erythema but no mucosal ulcerations. There are numerous and diffuse erythematous macules and papules present on the trunk and proximal extremities. Enlarged lymph nodes are palpated in the cervical, axillary, and inguinal areas. Laboratory results show eosinophilia (10%) and elevated AST (99 U/L) and ALT (102 U/L). Phenytoin level is 12~mg/dL (normal 10-20). What is the best next step in management of this patient?
explanation: This patient's presentation suggests anticonvulsant hypersensitivity syndrome (AHS) or drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome. AHS occurs within 2 months of starting aromatic anticonvulsants like phenytoin. Manifestations include fever, rash, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, and systemic organ involvement (eg, hepatitis). Diagnosis requires high suspicion; management includes supportive care and prompt discontinuation of the offending drug. Systemic corticosteroids are frequently used to help recovery. (Choice B) Contact isolation is for multidrug-resistant bacteria or enteric infections, not drug reactions. (Choices A, D, and E) Hepatitis viral panel and lumbar puncture are not useful for identifying AHS. Bone marrow biopsy might be considered to rule out malignancy only if the patient does not improve after discontinuing the drug. Educational objective: Anticonvulsant hypersensitivity syndrome is a serious disorder characterized by fever, rash, lymphadenopathy, and systemic organ involvement; management includes discontinuation of the offending drug and systemic glucocorticoids.

stem: A 35-year-old man comes to the office due to 4 weeks of generalized malaise, left-sided headache, and weakness of the right hand. The patient has a history of intravenous drug use, which led to hepatitis C and HIV infections. He has refused antiretroviral therapy, and his last known CD4 count was 298/mm^{3}3 months ago. He has never had an HIV-related opportunistic infection. Examination shows no oral thrush or enlarged lymph nodes. Erythematous macules are present on both palms. A 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the cardiac apex. Motor strength is 4/5 in the right upper extremity and 5/5 elsewhere. Reflexes are 3+ in the right upper extremity with an extensor plantar response on the right. Toxoplasma IgG antibodies are negative. CT scan of the head reveals a 2.4-cm, ring-enhancing, round mass with vasogenic edema at the grey-white matter junction in the left frontal lobe. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient with subacute headache and a single ring-enhancing lesion at the grey-white matter junction most likely has a brain abscess. His history of IV drug use, holosystolic murmur, and Janeway lesions (palmar macules) suggests underlying infectious endocarditis causing hematogenous dissemination. Brain abscesses typically show significant vasogenic edema or mass effect on imaging. (Choice E) Toxoplasmosis typically causes multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the basal ganglia and occurs in patients with CD4 counts <100 who have positive Toxoplasma IgG serology. (Choice C) Primary CNS lymphoma typically presents as a single, large (>4 cm) lesion in the subcortical white matter, usually with CD4 counts <50. (Choice B) HIV-associated encephalopathy presents with progressive dementia and brain atrophy, not focal ring-enhancing lesions. (Choice D) PML is a demyelinating disorder showing white matter lesions with no mass effect or enhancement. Educational objective: Brain abscess is characterized by single or multiple ring-enhancing lesions at the grey-white matter junction with significant vasogenic edema.

stem: An 84-year-old man is brought to the office by his daughter for increased confusion and agitation. He has a history of moderate Alzheimer dementia with worsening cognitive and functional status over the past 6 months. He now requires 24-hour supervision. The daughter notes the patient frequently wanders and has been more restless and agitated, especially in the evenings (sundowning). He frequently yells and is increasingly paranoid. The patient has no pain. Medications include donepezil, multivitamins, tamsulosin, and acetaminophen. Vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable. Complete blood count and chemistry panel are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's neuropsychiatric symptoms?
choice_a: Begin memantine on an increasing-dose schedule
choice_b: Plan for behavioral and environmental therapy
explanation: Nonpharmacologic interventions are preferred for the initial management of neuropsychiatric symptoms of dementia like agitation and paranoia. Behavioral methods include structured routines and distraction; environmental therapy includes exercise or music therapy. Pharmacotherapy is reserved for severe symptoms that pose a safety risk. (Choice A) Memantine has modest benefits for cognition but no significant effect on neuropsychiatric symptoms. (Choice C) Benzodiazepines (lorazepam) should be avoided due to side effects like falls, confusion, and paradoxical agitation. (Choice D) Low-dose antipsychotics (risperidone) have limited efficacy and are associated with increased mortality in elderly patients with dementia. They should be tried only if nonpharmacological strategies fail. (Choice E) SSRIs have not shown consistent efficacy for agitation unless it is related to a mood disturbance. Educational objective: Nonpharmacologic therapies are first-line interventions in dementia patients with behavioral disturbances.

stem: A 67-year-old woman with stable angina pectoris comes to the office for follow-up. She has occasional retrosternal chest pain on heavy exertion, which improves with nitroglycerin. She has had no headache or focal neurological symptoms. Medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes, peripheral vascular disease, and a 3.5-cm abdominal aortic aneurysm. Physical examination shows a carotid bruit. Duplex ultrasonography reveals complete occlusion of the right internal carotid artery and mild stenosis of the left internal carotid artery. Which of the following is the best management for this patient's carotid disease?
explanation: All patients with carotid artery atherosclerosis should receive medical management (aspirin, statin, control of hypertension/diabetes). This patient is asymptomatic (no TIA/stroke in the last 6 months). Complete occlusion of the right internal carotid artery in an asymptomatic patient typically indicates adequate collateral blood flow; therefore, carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is unlikely to provide benefit and is not recommended for complete occlusion. The left carotid has only mild stenosis (<50%), which also warrants medical therapy only. (Choice C) CEA is recommended for asymptomatic patients with high-grade (eg, 80-99%) stenosis, but not for complete occlusion or mild stenosis. (Choices A and B) Carotid stenting or bypass is generally reserved for patients who need revascularization but are poor surgical candidates.
